pli-tv-kd15:1.1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū nahāyamānā rukkhe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsenti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi.
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.2.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six rubbed their bodies—thighs, arms, chest, and back—against trees while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.4.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā nahāyamānā rukkhe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsessanti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi, seyyathāpi mallamuṭṭhikā gāmamoddavā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.4.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics do this? They’re just like boxers and city slickers who beautify their bodies!”
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.4.comm: “Boxers” renders mallamuṭṭhikā and “city slickers who beautify their bodies” is for gāmamoddavā. In relation to mallamuṭṭhikā Sp 4.243 simply says mallamuṭṭhikāti muṭṭhikamallā, which is not very helpful. Muṭṭhikamallā is then explained at Sp-yoj 4.243: Muṭṭhikamallāti muṭṭhikena mathanti aññamaññaṁ hiṁsantīti, “Muṭṭhikamallā: hitting with a fist, they hurt each other.” As regards gāmamoddavā, Sp 4.243 says: Gāmamuddavāti chavirāgamaṇḍanānuyuttā nāgarikamanussā. Gāmamoddavātipi pāṭho; esevattho, “Gāmamuddavā means townspeople who are devoted to beautifying their skin with color; gāmamoddavā is another reading, with the same meaning.” See OPM, pp. 13-20 and 27, for a detailed discussion of these two phrases. The discussion in OPM concludes that “the word formation of gāmaphoḍava and the first member of this compound remain obscure.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.5.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.5.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.6.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā bhikkhū paṭipucchi—
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.7.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.8.pli: “saccaṃ kira, bhikkhave, chabbaggiyā bhikkhū nahāyamānā rukkhe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsenti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpī”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.8.eng: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are doing this?”

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.11.pli: “ananucchavikaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ moghapurisānaṃ ananulomikaṃ appatirūpaṃ assāmaṇakaṃ akappiyaṃ akaraṇīyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.11.eng: “It’s not suitable for those foolish men, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.12.pli: Kathañhi nāma te, bhikkhave, moghapurisā nahāyamānā rukkhe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsessanti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi?

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.15.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.16.pli: “na, bhikkhave, nahāyamānena bhikkhunā rukkhe kāyo ugghaṃsetabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:1.1.16.eng: “You shouldn’t rub your body against a tree while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.1.17.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū nahāyamānā thambhe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsenti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi.
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six rubbed their bodies—thighs, arms, chest, and back—against posts while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.3.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā nahāyamānā thambhe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsessanti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi, seyyathāpi mallamuṭṭhikā gāmamoddavā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.3.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics do this? They’re just like boxers and city slickers who beautify their bodies!”

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.4.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.4.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.5.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.8.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.9.pli: “na, bhikkhave, nahāyamānena bhikkhunā thambhe kāyo ugghaṃsetabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.9.eng: “You shouldn’t rub your body against a post while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.11.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū nahāyamānā kuṭṭe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsenti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi.
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.11.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six rubbed their bodies—thighs, arms, chest, and back—against walls while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.13.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā nahāyamānā kuṭṭe kāyaṃ ugghaṃsessanti, ūrumpi bāhumpi urampi piṭṭhimpi, seyyathāpi mallamuṭṭhikā gāmamoddavā”ti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.13.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics do this? They’re just like boxers and city slickers who beautify their bodies!” …

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.14.pli: “na, bhikkhave, nahāyamānena bhikkhunā kuṭṭe kāyo ugghaṃsetabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:1.2.14.eng: “You shouldn’t rub your body against a wall while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.2.15.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū aṭṭāne nahāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six rubbed their bodies—thighs, arms, chest, and back—against a rubbing board while bathing.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.1.comm: Sp 4.243: Aṭṭāne nhāyantīti ettha aṭṭānaṁ nāma rukkhaṁ phalakaṁ viya tacchetvā aṭṭhapadākārena rājiyo chinditvā nhānatitthe nikhaṇanti, tattha cuṇṇāni ākiritvā manussā kāyaṁ ghaṁsanti, “Aṭṭāne nahāyanti: here an aṭṭāna means: having carved a tree to become like a plank, having cut lines in a cross-wise pattern, having dug it in at a bathing ford, people sprinkle powder there and rub their bodies.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.2.eng: People complained and criticized them, “How can the Sakyan monastics do this?

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.3.eng: They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.4.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.5.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.9.eng: “You shouldn’t rub your body against a rubbing board while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.11.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū gandhabbahatthakena nahāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.11.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six bathed with a wooden rubbing-hand.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.11.comm: Sp 4.243: Gandhabbahatthakenāti nhānatitthe ṭhapitena dārumayahatthena, tena kira cuṇṇāni gahetvā manussā sarīraṁ ghaṁsanti, “Gandhabbahatthakena: having taken powders with a hand made of wood, which is kept at a bathing ford, people rub their bodies.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.12.eng: People complained and criticized them, “How can the Sakyan monastics do this?

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.13.eng: They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.14.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.14.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.15.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.16.eng: “You shouldn’t bathe with a wooden rubbing-hand.

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.17.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.18.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū kuruvindakasuttiyā nahāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.18.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six bathed with a string of cinnabar beads.
pli-tv-kd15:1.3.18.comm: Sp 4.243: Kuruvindakasuttiyāti kuruvindakapāsāṇacuṇṇāni lākhāya bandhitvā kataguḷikakalāpako vuccati, taṁ ubhosu antesu gahetvā sarīraṁ ghaṁsanti, “Kuruvindakasuttiyā: having bound powder from a cinnabar-stone with resin, it is said a string of beads is made; having grasped it at both ends, they rub their bodies.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.19.eng: People complained and criticized them, “How can the Sakyan monastics do this?

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.20.eng: They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.22.eng: “You shouldn’t bathe with a string of cinnabar beads.

pli-tv-kd15:1.3.23.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū viggayha parikammaṃ kārāpenti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.4.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six massaged one another.
pli-tv-kd15:1.4.1.comm: Viggayha parikammaṁ kārāpenti, literally, “Having stretched out, they caused a massage to be done.” Sp 4.243: Viggayha parikammaṁ kārāpentīti aññamaññaṁ sarīrena sarīraṁ ghaṁsanti, “Viggayha parikammaṁ kārāpenti: they rubbed each other, body with body.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.2.eng: People complained and criticized them, “How can the Sakyan monastics do this?

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.3.eng: They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū mallakena nahāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.4.7.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six bathed with an ornamented scrubber.
pli-tv-kd15:1.4.7.comm: Sp 4.243: Mallakaṁ nāma makaradantake chinditvā mallakamūlasaṇṭhānena kataṁ mallakanti vuccati, “Mallaka: having cut a shark-teeth pattern at the position of the base of the mallaka, it is called a mallaka.” It is not clear what this refers to, apart from the fact that it is decorated. I follow the suggestion in PED.

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.8.eng: People complained and criticized them, “How can the Sakyan monastics do this?

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.9.eng: They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!” …

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.11.eng: “You shouldn’t bathe with an ornamented scrubber.

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.12.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno kacchurogābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.4.13.eng: Soon afterwards a certain monk had an itchy skin disease.

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.14.pli: Na tassa vinā mallakena phāsu hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.4.14.eng: He was not comfortable without a scrubber.

pli-tv-kd15:1.4.16.eng: “I allow a plain scrubber for those who are sick.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu jarādubbalo nahāyamāno na sakkoti attano kāyaṃ ugghaṃsetuṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:1.5.1.eng: At that time a monk who was weak from old age was unable to rub his own body while bathing.

pli-tv-kd15:1.5.3.comm: Sp 4.244: Ukkāsikanti vatthavaṭṭiṁ, “Ukkāsika means a sheath of cloth.”

pli-tv-kd15:1.5.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū piṭṭhiparikammaṃ kātuṃ kukkuccāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:1.5.4.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not give back massages.

pli-tv-kd15:1.5.6.eng: “I allow a massage with the flat of the hand.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū vallikaṃ dhārenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:2.1.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six wore earrings,
pli-tv-kd15:2.1.1.comm: Sp 4.245: Vallikāti kaṇṇato nikkhantamuttolambakādīnaṁ etaṁ adhivacanaṁ, “Vallikā: this is a term for a pearl, etc., hanging and protruding from the ear.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.2.comm: Sp 4.245: pāmaṅganti yaṅkiñci palambakasuttaṁ, “Pāmaṅga: whatever is a hanging thread.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.5.comm: Sp 4.245: Ovaṭṭikanti valayaṁ, “An ovaṭṭika is a bangle.” This is further explained at Vmv 4.245: Valayanti hatthapādavalayaṁ, “A bangle: a bangle for the hands or the feet.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.6.comm: Sp 4.245: Kāyūrādīni pākaṭāneva, akkhakānaṁ heṭṭhā bāhābharaṇaṁ yaṅkiñci ābharaṇaṁ na vaṭṭati, “Just ordinary kāyūras, etc.; any arm-ornaments below the collar-bone, are not allowable.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.7.comm: Hatthābharaṇa, literally, “a hand ornament”, is not further explained in the commentaries.

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.10.eng: “… They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.11.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:2.1.11.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people.

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.12.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.13.pli: “Saccaṃ kira, bhikkhave, chabbaggiyā bhikkhū vallikaṃ dhārenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:2.1.13.eng: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are wearing these things?”

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.14.pli: pāmaṅgaṃ dhārenti, kaṇṭhasuttakaṃ dhārenti, kaṭisuttakaṃ dhārenti, ovaṭṭikaṃ dhārenti, kāyuraṃ dhārenti, hatthābharaṇaṃ dhārenti, aṅgulimuddikaṃ dhārentī”ti?

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.17.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:2.1.26.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū dīghe kese dhārenti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.2.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six grew their hair long.

pli-tv-kd15:2.2.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:2.2.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:2.2.7.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, dumāsikaṃ vā duvaṅgulaṃ vā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.2.7.eng: I allow you to grow it to a length of 3.5 centimeters or for two months at the most.”
pli-tv-kd15:2.2.7.comm: That is, two fingerbreadths. For a discussion of the aṅgula, see sugata in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:2.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū kocchena kese osaṇṭhenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:2.3.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six brushed their hair,

pli-tv-kd15:2.3.2.pli: phaṇakena kese osaṇṭhenti, hatthaphaṇakena kese osaṇṭhenti, sitthatelakena kese osaṇṭhenti, udakatelakena kese osaṇṭhenti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.3.2.eng: and they combed it, combed it with their hands, smoothed it with beeswax, and smoothed it with water and oil.

pli-tv-kd15:2.3.4.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:2.3.6.eng: “You shouldn’t brush your hair, or comb it, comb it with your hands,

pli-tv-kd15:2.3.8.eng: or smooth it with water and oil.

pli-tv-kd15:2.3.9.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū ādāsepi udakapattepi mukhanimittaṃ olokenti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.4.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six looked at their faces in mirrors and in bowls of water.

pli-tv-kd15:2.4.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:2.4.5.pli: “Na, bhikkhave, ādāse vā udakapatte vā mukhanimittaṃ oloketabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:2.4.5.eng: “You shouldn’t look at your face in a mirror or in a bowl of water.

pli-tv-kd15:2.4.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.4.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno mukhe vaṇo hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.4.7.eng: Soon afterwards a certain monk had a sore on his face.

pli-tv-kd15:2.4.14.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, ābādhappaccayā ādāse vā udakapatte vā mukhanimittaṃ oloketun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.4.14.eng: “I allow you to look at your face in a mirror or in a bowl of water if you have a disease.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū mukhaṃ ālimpanti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:2.5.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six used facial ointments,

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.2.pli: mukhaṃ ummaddenti, mukhaṃ cuṇṇenti, manosilikāya mukhaṃ lañchenti, aṅgarāgaṃ karonti, mukharāgaṃ karonti, aṅgarāgamukharāgaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.5.2.eng: applied facial creams, powdered their face, applied rouge to their face, wore cosmetics on the body, wore cosmetics on the face, and wore cosmetics on the body and face.
pli-tv-kd15:2.5.2.comm: “Applied facial creams” renders mukhaṁ ummaddenti. The verb ummaddeti normally just means “rubs” or “massages”, but here the contexts required the application of some kind of cosmetic or cream. Sp 3.247: Ummaddentīti nānāummaddanehi ummaddenti, “Ummaddenti: they rub with various creams.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.4.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.7.pli: na mukhaṃ ummadditabbaṃ, na mukhaṃ cuṇṇetabbaṃ, na manosilikāya mukhaṃ lañchetabbaṃ, na aṅgarāgo kātabbo, na mukharāgo kātabbo, na aṅgarāgamukharāgo kātabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:2.5.7.eng: apply facial creams, powder your face, apply rouge to your face, wear cosmetics on the body, wear cosmetics on the face, or wear cosmetics on the body and face.

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.9.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno cakkhurogābādho hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.5.9.eng: Soon afterwards a certain monk had an eye disease.

pli-tv-kd15:2.5.11.eng: “I allow facial ointments for those who are sick.”

pli-tv-kd15:2.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahe giraggasamajjo hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.6.1.eng: On one occasion in Rājagaha there was a hilltop fair,

pli-tv-kd15:2.6.2.eng: and the monks from the group of six went to see it.

pli-tv-kd15:2.6.4.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā naccampi gītampi vāditampi dassanāya gacchissanti, seyyathāpi gihī kāmabhogino”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:2.6.4.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics go and see dancing, singing, and music? They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:2.6.6.pli: “Na, bhikkhave, naccaṃ vā gītaṃ vā vāditaṃ vā dassanāya gantabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:2.6.6.eng: “You shouldn’t go and see dancing, singing, and music.

pli-tv-kd15:2.6.7.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū āyatakena gītassarena dhammaṃ gāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six were singing the Teaching with a drawn-out voice.

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.3.pli: “yatheva mayaṃ gāyāma, evamevime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā āyatakena gītassarena dhammaṃ gāyantī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.3.eng: “These Sakyan monastics sing with a drawn-out voice just like we do.”

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.4.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.4.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people,

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.5.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.5.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.6.pli: “kathañhi nāma chabbaggiyā bhikkhū āyatakena gītassarena dhammaṃ gāyissantī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.6.eng: “How can the monks from the group of six sing like this?”

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.7.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.8.eng: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are singing like this?”

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.10.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.11.pli: “pañcime, bhikkhave, ādīnavā āyatakena gītassarena dhammaṃ gāyantassa.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.11.eng: “There are these five drawbacks to singing the Teaching with a drawn-out voice:

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.12.pli: Attanāpi tasmiṃ sare sārajjati, parepi tasmiṃ sare sārajjanti, gahapatikāpi ujjhāyanti, sarakuttimpi nikāmayamānassa samādhissa bhaṅgo hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati—
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.12.eng: one delights in the sound; others delight in the sound; householders criticize it; for one who takes pleasure in performing with the voice, the concentration is disrupted; later generations follow one’s example.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.12.comm: “Performing with the voice” renders sarakutti. According to DOP, kutti means “arranging, dressing, preparation; action; forming; contriving”. Sp 4.249: Sarakuttinti sarakiriyaṁ, “Sarakuttiṁ means activity/performance with the voice”.

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.13.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā āyatakena gītassarena dhammaṃ gāyantassa.

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.14.pli: Na, bhikkhave, āyatakena gītassarena dhammo gāyitabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:3.1.14.eng: You shouldn’t sing the Teaching with a drawn-out voice.

pli-tv-kd15:3.1.15.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:3.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū sarabhaññe kukkuccāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:3.2.1.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not chant.
pli-tv-kd15:3.2.1.comm: “Chant” renders sarabhañña. PED says: “Intoning, a particular mode of reciting.” Sp 4.249: Sarabhaññanti sarena bhaṇanaṁ, “Sarabhañña means reciting with intonation.” Sara can mean either “voice” or “intonation”. But since “voice” would be redundant in the present context (“reciting with a voice”), intonation seems to be the likely meaning.

pli-tv-kd15:4.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū bāhiralomiṃ uṇṇiṃ dhārenti.
pli-tv-kd15:4.1.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six wore fleecy woolen robes with fleece on the outside.

pli-tv-kd15:4.1.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:4.1.5.eng: “You shouldn’t wear a fleecy woolen robe with fleece on the outside.

pli-tv-kd15:4.1.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa ārāme ambā phalino honti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.1.eng: On one occasion when the mango trees in King Bimbisāra’s park were bearing fruit,

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.2.pli: Raññā māgadhena seniyena bimbisārena anuññātaṃ hoti—

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.3.eng: to eat as many mangoes as they wished.

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.4.pli: Chabbaggiyā bhikkhū taruṇaññeva ambaṃ pātāpetvā paribhuñjiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.4.eng: The monks from the group of six plucked and ate them all, even the unripe ones.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.4.comm: Vmv 4.250: Pāḷiyaṁ taruṇaññeva ambanti taruṇaṁ asañjātabījaṁ eva ambaphalaṁ, “In the Canonical text, taruṇaññeva ambanṁ means: a mango fruit even with undeveloped seed.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.5.pli: Rañño ca māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa ambena attho hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.5.eng: Just then the king needed mangoes.

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.6.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro manusse āṇāpesi—

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.7.eng: “Go to the park and bring back mangoes.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.8.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho te manussā rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa paṭissutvā ārāmaṃ gantvā ārāmapālaṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.8.eng: Saying, “Yes, sir,” they went to the park and said to the park keeper,

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.9.eng: “The king needs mangoes. Please get some.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.11.eng: The monks plucked and ate them all, including the unripe ones.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.12.pli: Atha kho te manussā rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.12.eng: They reported it to the king. He said,

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.13.pli: “Suparibhuttaṃ, bhaṇe, ayyehi ambaṃ, api ca bhagavatā mattā vaṇṇitā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.13.eng: “It’s good that the venerables have eaten the mangoes. Still, the Buddha has praised moderation.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.15.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā na mattaṃ jānitvā rañño ambaṃ paribhuñjissantī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.15.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics eat the king’s mangoes without moderation?”

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.16.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:5.1.16.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.17.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:5.1.19.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa pūgassa saṅghabhattaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards a certain association was offering a meal to the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.3.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept it.

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa pūgassa saṅghabhattaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.2.6.eng: Soon afterwards a certain association was offering a meal to the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.7.pli: Te na pariyāpuṇiṃsu ambapesikaṃ kātuṃ, bhattagge sakaleheva ambehi denti.
pli-tv-kd15:5.2.7.eng: They were unable to prepare mango pieces and so gave whole mangoes in the dining hall.

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.8.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept them.

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.10.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahi samaṇakappehi phalaṃ paribhuñjituṃ—
pli-tv-kd15:5.2.10.eng: I allow you to eat fruit that’s allowable for monastics for any of five reasons:

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.11.pli: aggiparicitaṃ, satthaparicitaṃ, nakhaparicitaṃ, abījaṃ, nibbattabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:5.2.11.eng: it’s been damaged by fire, a knife, or a fingernail, or it’s seedless, or the seeds have been removed.”

pli-tv-kd15:5.2.12.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imehi pañcahi samaṇakappehi phalaṃ paribhuñjitun”ti.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṅkato hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.1.eng: On one occasion a monk had been bitten by a snake and died.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.3.pli: “Na hi nūna so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phari.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.3.eng: “That monk hadn’t spread good will to the four royal snake clans.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.3.comm: The following is parallel to AN 4.67:1.1.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.4.pli: Sace hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phareyya, na hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṃ kareyya.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.4.eng: Had he done so, he wouldn’t have died.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.6.pli: Virūpakkhaṃ ahirājakulaṃ, erāpathaṃ ahirājakulaṃ, chabyāputtaṃ ahirājakulaṃ, kaṇhāgotamaṃ ahirājakulaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.6.eng: The Virūpakkhas, the Erāpathas, the Chabyāputtas, and the Kaṇhāgotamas.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.7.pli: Na hi nūna so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phari.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.8.pli: Sace hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena phareyya, na hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ahinā daṭṭho kālaṃ kareyya.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.9.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imāni cattāri ahirājakulāni mettena cittena pharituṃ, attaguttiyā attarakkhāya attaparittaṃ kātuṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.9.eng: To protect yourselves, monks, you should spread good will to these four royal snake clans.
pli-tv-kd15:6.1.9.comm: We see here that it is the spreading of good will that matters, not the chant as such. This accords with the Mettānisaṁsa Sutta at AN 11.15, which states that one is protected from various things only if one develops love to a high level. For the rendering “should” for anujānāmi, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.10.eng: And it should be done like this:

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.11.eng: I have good will toward the Virūpakkhas,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.12.eng: Toward the Erāpathas I have good will;

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.13.eng: I have good will toward the Chabyāputtas,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.15.eng: I have good will toward the legless,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.16.eng: Toward the two-legged I have good will;

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.17.eng: I have good will toward the four-legged,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.19.eng: May the legless not hurt me,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.20.eng: May the two-legged not hurt me.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.21.eng: May the four-legged not hurt me,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.22.eng: May the many-legged not hurt me.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.25.eng: May they all have good fortune,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.26.eng: May none meet with anything bad.

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.33.pli: Katā me rakkhā kataṃ me parittaṃ,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.35.eng: I pay homage to the Buddha,

pli-tv-kd15:6.1.36.eng: To the seven fully awakened Buddhas.”

pli-tv-kd15:7.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu anabhiratiyā pīḷito attano aṅgajātaṃ chindi.
pli-tv-kd15:7.1.1.eng: On one occasion a monk who was plagued by lust cut off his own penis.

pli-tv-kd15:7.1.2.eng: They told the Buddha. He said,

pli-tv-kd15:7.1.3.pli: “Aññamhi so, bhikkhave, moghapuriso chetabbamhi, aññaṃ chindi.
pli-tv-kd15:7.1.3.eng: “This fool has cut off one thing, when he should’ve cut off something else.

pli-tv-kd15:7.1.4.eng: You shouldn’t cut off your own penis.

pli-tv-kd15:7.1.5.eng: If you do, you commit a serious offense.”

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa mahagghassa candanassa candanagaṇṭhi uppannā hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.1.eng: On one occasion a wealthy merchant of Rājagaha had obtained a valuable block of sandalwood.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.3.eng: “Why don’t I have a bowl carved from this block of sandal?

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.4.pli: Lekhañca me paribhogaṃ bhavissati, pattañca dānaṃ dassāmī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.4.eng: I’d use the chips myself, but give the bowl away as a gift.”

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.5.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhi tāya candanagaṇṭhiyā pattaṃ lekhāpetvā sikkāya uḍḍitvā veḷagge ālaggetvā veḷuparamparāya bandhitvā evamāha—
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.5.eng: He then had a bowl carved, put it in a carrying net, hung it at the end of a succession of vertical bamboo poles, and announced,
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.5.comm: “Carrying net” renders sikkā. Vin-vn-ṭ 91: Sikkāyāti olambikādhāre, “Sikkā means a holder for hanging.” CPD, under uḍḍeti, says, “To put in a sling or carrying net”, evidently referring to the sikkā.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.6.pli: “yo samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā arahā ceva iddhimā ca dinnaṃyeva pattaṃ oharatū”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.6.eng: “I’ll give this bowl to any perfected monastic or brahmin who brings it down by supernormal power.”

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.7.pli: Atha kho pūraṇo kassapo yena rājagahako seṭṭhi tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājagahakaṃ seṭṭhiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.7.eng: Pūraṇa Kassapa went to that merchant and said,

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.8.pli: “ahañhi, gahapati, arahā ceva iddhimā ca, dehi me pattan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.8.eng: “I’m perfected and have supernormal powers. Give me the bowl.”

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.9.pli: “Sace, bhante, āyasmā arahā ceva iddhimā ca dinnaṃyeva pattaṃ oharatū”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.9.eng: “If you’re perfected and have supernormal powers, then bring it down and it’s yours.”

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.10.eng: The same thing happened with Makkhali Gosāla,

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.14.pli: nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto yena rājagahako seṭṭhi tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā rājagahakaṃ seṭṭhiṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.14.eng: and the Jain ascetic from Ñātika.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.15.pli: “ahañhi, gahapati, arahā ceva iddhimā ca, dehi me pattan”ti.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.16.pli: “Sace, bhante, āyasmā arahā ceva iddhimā ca, dinnaṃyeva pattaṃ oharatū”ti.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno āyasmā ca piṇḍolabhāradvājo pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.17.eng: Soon afterwards, after robing up in the morning, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna and Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja took their bowls and robes and entered Rājagaha for alms.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.18.pli: Atha kho āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājo āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.19.pli: “āyasmā kho mahāmoggallāno arahā ceva iddhimā ca.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.19.eng: “Venerable, you’re perfected and have supernormal powers.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.20.eng: If you go and bring down that bowl,

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.22.pli: “Āyasmā kho bhāradvājo arahā ceva iddhimā ca.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.22.eng: “Venerable, you too are perfected and have supernormal powers.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.25.pli: Atha kho āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājo vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā taṃ pattaṃ gahetvā tikkhattuṃ rājagahaṃ anupariyāyi.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.25.eng: Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja then rose into the air, took hold of that bowl, and circled around Rājagaha three times.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.26.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahako seṭṭhi saputtadāro sake nivesane ṭhito hoti pañjaliko namassamāno—
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.26.eng: Just then that merchant, together with his wives and children, was standing in his own house, raising his joined palms in homage, thinking,

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.27.pli: idheva, bhante, ayyo bhāradvājo amhākaṃ nivesane patiṭṭhātūti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.27.eng: “May Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja land right here at our house.”

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.28.pli: Atha kho āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājo rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa nivesane patiṭṭhāsi.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.28.eng: And Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja did just that.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.29.pli: Atha kho rājagahako seṭṭhi āyasmato piṇḍolabhāradvājassa hatthato pattaṃ gahetvā mahagghassa khādanīyassa pūretvā āyasmato piṇḍolabhāradvājassa adāsi.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.29.eng: The merchant then took the bowl from his hands, filled it with expensive fresh foods, and gave it back to Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja,
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.29.comm: For the rendering “fresh food” for khādanīya, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:8.1.30.pli: Atha kho āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājo taṃ pattaṃ gahetvā ārāmaṃ agamāsi.
pli-tv-kd15:8.1.30.eng: who then left for the monastery.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.2.pli: ayyena kira piṇḍolabhāradvājena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa patto ohāritoti.
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.2.eng: that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja had taken down the merchant’s bowl,

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.3.pli: Te ca manussā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā āyasmantaṃ piṇḍolabhāradvājaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhiṃsu.
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.3.eng: and making a great uproar, they followed right behind him.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.5.eng: the Buddha asked Venerable Ānanda what it was,

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.6.pli: “kiṃ nu kho so, ānanda, uccāsaddo mahāsaddo”ti?

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.7.pli: “Āyasmatā, bhante, piṇḍolabhāradvājena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa patto ohārito.
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.7.eng: and Ānanda told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.9.pli: ayyena kira piṇḍolabhāradvājena rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa patto ohāritoti.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.10.pli: Te ca, bhante, manussā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā āyasmantaṃ piṇḍolabhāradvājaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.11.pli: So eso, bhante, bhagavā uccāsaddo mahāsaddo”ti.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.12.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā āyasmantaṃ piṇḍolabhāradvājaṃ paṭipucchi—
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.12.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha of monks gathered and questioned Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja:

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.13.pli: “saccaṃ kira tayā, bhāradvāja, rājagahakassa seṭṭhissa patto ohārito”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.13.eng: “Is it true, Bhāradvāja, that you brought down that merchant’s bowl?”

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.16.pli: “ananucchavikaṃ, bhāradvāja, ananulomikaṃ appatirūpaṃ assāmaṇakaṃ akappiyaṃ akaraṇīyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.16.eng: “It’s not suitable, Bhāradvāja, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.17.pli: Kathañhi nāma tvaṃ, bhāradvāja, chavassa dārupattassa kāraṇā gihīnaṃ uttari manussadhammaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassessasi.
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.17.eng: How could you show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders for the sake of a miserable wooden bowl?

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.18.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, mātugāmo chavassa māsakarūpassa kāraṇā kopinaṃ dasseti;
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.18.eng: It’s just like a woman showing her private parts for a miserable māsaka coin.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.19.pli: evameva kho tayā, bhāradvāja, chavassa dārupattassa kāraṇā gihīnaṃ uttari manussadhammaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassitaṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.22.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.23.eng: “You shouldn’t show a superhuman ability, a wonder of supernormal power, to householders.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.24.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.25.pli: Bhindathetaṃ, bhikkhave, dārupattaṃ sakalikaṃ sakalikaṃ katvā, bhikkhūnaṃ añjanupapisanaṃ detha.
pli-tv-kd15:8.2.25.eng: Now destroy that wooden bowl and turn it into splinters. Give these to the monks to use as scent in ointments.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.26.eng: And you shouldn’t use a wooden bowl.

pli-tv-kd15:8.2.27.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvace patte dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:9.1.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six used luxurious bowls made with gold and silver.
pli-tv-kd15:9.1.1.comm: It is not clear whether sovaṇṇamayaṁ rūpiyamayaṁ means “made of gold or silver” or “made with gold or silver”. It seems unlikely, however, that a bowl made partly of gold/silver would be acceptable, since it would still be considered luxurious. Moreover, just below the text mentions bowls made of/with crystal and gems (maṇimayo … veḷuriyamayo). It is hard to imagine that a bowl could be made of any of these in its entirety. It seems more likely that they were used as decorations. In either case “made with” seems preferable to “made of”. With smaller requisites, however, “made of” gold and silver may be the preferable rendering. The commentaries are silent.

pli-tv-kd15:9.1.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:9.1.5.eng: “You shouldn’t use almsbowls made with gold,

pli-tv-kd15:9.1.8.comm: “Beryl” renders veḷuriya. The commentary at Sp-ṭ 1.281 says: Veḷuriyoti vaṁsavaṇṇamaṇi, “The bamboo-colored gem is called veḷuriya.” According to PED veḷuriya is lapis lazuli, which cannot be correct because lapis lazuli is blue.

pli-tv-kd15:9.1.15.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:9.1.16.eng: I allow two kinds of almsbowls:

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pattamūlaṃ ghaṃsiyati.
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.1.eng: At that time the bottoms of the bowls became scratched.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacāni pattamaṇḍalāni dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.4.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six used luxurious bowl rests made with gold and silver.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.6.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.9.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.10.eng: I allow two kinds of bowl rests:

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.11.eng: bowl-rests made of tin and a bowl-rests made of lead.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.12.eng: There were thick bowl rests on which the bowls did not sit properly.
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.12.comm: Sp-ṭ 4.253: Na acchupiyantīti na suphassitāni honti, “Na acchupiyanti: not touching properly.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.14.eng: “I allow you to carve them out.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.15.eng: There were marks left from the carving.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.17.eng: “I allow you to cut a shark-teeth pattern.”
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.17.comm: “A shark-teeth pattern” renders makaradantaka, literally, “like the teeth of a makara”. In later Buddhism the makara is the name of a mythological marine animal, but what it refers to in this context is not clear. According to Sp-yoj 4.243 makara is the name of a certain species of fish: Makaradantaketi makaranāmakassa macchassa dantasadise dante, “Teeth like the teeth of a fish called makara.” Vin-vn-ṭ 3048: Makaradantakanti girikūṭākāraṁ, “Makaradantaka means making (a design) like the peak of a hill.” PED suggests “the tooth of a swordfish”, but apparently swordfish do not have teeth. Given that the makara were fearsome creatures and that their teeth looked like the peak of a hill, presumably meaning that their teeth were pointed, “shark teeth” seems like a reasonable guess.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.18.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū citrāni pattamaṇḍalāni dhārenti rūpakākiṇṇāni bhittikammakatāni.
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.18.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six used colorful bowl rests, decorated like walls.
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.18.comm: Bhittikamma, literally, “wall-work”. Sp 4.297: Bhittikammanti nānāvaṇṇehi vibhittirājikaraṇaṁ, “Bhittikamma means making separate lines by means of many colors.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.19.eng: As they were walking about, they showed them off in the streets.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.21.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.23.pli: “Na, bhikkhave, citrāni pattamaṇḍalāni dhāretabbāni rūpakākiṇṇāni bhittikammakatāni.
pli-tv-kd15:9.2.23.eng: “You shouldn’t use colorful bowl rests, decorated like a wall.

pli-tv-kd15:9.2.24.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū sodakaṃ pattaṃ paṭisāmenti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.3.1.eng: At this time there were monks who put away their bowls while still wet.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.4.eng: “You shouldn’t put away your bowl while still wet.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.5.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.6.eng: You should sun your bowl and then put it away.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū sodakaṃ pattaṃ otāpenti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.3.7.eng: Soon afterwards there were monks who sunned their bowls while still wet.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.10.eng: “You shouldn’t sun your bowl while still wet.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.11.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.12.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, vodakaṃ katvā otāpetvā pattaṃ paṭisāmetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.3.12.eng: You should dry the bowl and then sun it before you put it away.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū uṇhe pattaṃ nidahanti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.3.13.eng: Monks left their bowls in the heat of the sun.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.16.eng: “You shouldn’t leave your bowl in the heat of the sun.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.17.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:9.3.18.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, muhuttaṃ uṇhe otāpetvā pattaṃ paṭisāmetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.3.18.eng: You should sun it in the heat for a short time and then put it away.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā pattā ajjhokāse anādhārā nikkhittā honti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.1.eng: On one occasion a number of almsbowls had been put down outside without support.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.2.eng: A whirlwind rolled the bowls around and as a result they broke.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.2.comm: Sp 4.254: Āvaṭṭitvāti aññamaññaṁ paharitvā, “Āvaṭṭitva: (the bowls) struck one another.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.4.comm: Sp 4.254: Pattādhārakanti ettha “dantavallivettādīhi kate bhūmiādhārake tayo, dāruādhārake dve patte uparūpari ṭhapetuṁ vaṭṭatī”ti kurundiyaṁ vuttaṁ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṁ pana vuttaṁ – “bhūmiādhārake tiṇṇaṁ pattānaṁ anokāso, dve ṭhapetuṁ vaṭṭati”, “Pattādhāraka: in the Kurundī it is said: in a tiered rack made of ivory, creepers, cane, etc., three bowls may be placed on top of one another; in a rack made of wood, two bowls. But in the Mahāaṭṭhakathā it is said: in a tiered rack, there is no occasion for three bowls, but placing two is allowed.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū miḍḍhante pattaṃ nikkhipanti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.5.eng: On one occasion there were monks who had put their bowls on the edge of a bench.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.8.eng: “You shouldn’t put your almsbowl on the edge of a bench.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.8.comm: Sp 4.254: Miḍḍhanteti ālindakamiḍḍhikādīnaṁ ante, “Miḍḍhante means on the edge of a porch bench, etc.” See CPD, sv. ālindakamiḍḍhika.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.9.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū paribhaṇḍante pattaṃ nikkhipanti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.10.eng: On one occasion there were monks who had put their bowls on the edge of a ledge.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.13.eng: “You shouldn’t put your almsbowl on the edge of a ledge.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.13.comm: Sp 4.254: Paribhaṇḍanteti bāhirapasse katāya tanukamiḍḍhikāya ante, “Paribhaṇḍante means on the edge of a small bench made on an external slope.” Vmv 4.254: Tanukamiḍḍhikāyāti vedikāya, “On a small bench means on a ledge (or railing).”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.14.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.15.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū chamāya pattaṃ nikkujjanti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.15.eng: At that time the monks put their bowls upside down on the ground.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.16.eng: The edges of the bowls were scratched.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.19.eng: The grass was eaten by termites.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.22.eng: The cloth was eaten by termites.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.24.comm: Sp 4.254: Pattamāḷakaṁ iṭṭhakāhi vā dārūhi vā kātuṁ vaṭṭati, “Pattamāḷaka: made of bricks or wood is allowed.” Sp-yoj 4.254: Pattamāḷakanti pattassa ṭhapanatthāya kataṁ aṭṭaṁ, “Pattamāḷaka: a platform made for the purpose of placing the bowl.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.25.eng: The bowls fell off the platform and broke.
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.25.comm: I here follow the PTS reading, pattamāḷakā, rather than the MS reading of pattamāḷako. According to the PTS reading the bowl fell from the platform, whereas on the MS reading the platform itself fell.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.27.eng: “I allow a storage container for almsbowls.”
pli-tv-kd15:9.4.27.comm: Sp 4.254: Pattakuṇḍolikāti mahāmukhakuṇḍasaṇṭhānā bhaṇḍakukkhalikā vuccati, “A pot for goods in the appearance of a pot with a large mouth is called a pattakuṇḍolika.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.28.eng: The bowls were scratched in the storage containers.

pli-tv-kd15:9.4.33.eng: “I allow a shoulder strap and a string for fastening.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū bhittikhilepi nāgadantakepi pattaṃ laggenti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.1.eng: At that time there were monks who hung their bowls from wall pegs.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.1.comm: Bhittikhilepi nāgadantakepi, literally, “wall pegs and elephant tusks”. These are different kinds of pegs and I have not tried to differentiate between them.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.2.eng: The bowls fell down and broke.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.5.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū mañce pattaṃ nikkhipanti, satisammosā nisīdantā ottharitvā pattaṃ bhindenti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.6.eng: At that time there were monks who placed their bowls on beds. Sitting down absentmindedly, they crushed the bowls, breaking them.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.8.eng: “You shouldn’t place your bowl on a bed.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.9.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū pīṭhe pattaṃ nikkhipanti, satisammosā nisīdantā ottharitvā pattaṃ bhindenti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.10.eng: At that time monks placed their bowls on benches. Sitting down absentmindedly, they crushed the bowls, breaking them.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.12.eng: “You shouldn’t place your bowl on a bench.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.13.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.14.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū aṅke pattaṃ nikkhipanti, satisammosā uṭṭhahanti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.14.eng: At that time there were monks who put their bowls in their laps. When they got up absentmindedly,

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.15.eng: the bowls fell down and broke.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.17.eng: “You shouldn’t put your bowl in your lap.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.18.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.19.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū chatte pattaṃ nikkhipanti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.19.eng: At one time there were monks who put their bowls on a sunshade.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.20.pli: Vātamaṇḍalikāya chattaṃ ukkhipiyati paripatitvā patto bhijjati.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.20.eng: A whirlwind lifted the sunshade, and the bowls fell down and broke.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.22.eng: “You shouldn’t put your bowl on a sunshade.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.23.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.24.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū pattahatthā kavāṭaṃ paṇāmenti.
pli-tv-kd15:9.5.24.eng: At that time there were monks who opened doors with a bowl in their hand.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.25.eng: The doors swung back and the bowls broke.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.27.eng: “You shouldn’t open a door with an almsbowl in your hand.

pli-tv-kd15:9.5.28.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū tumbakaṭāhe piṇḍāya caranti.
pli-tv-kd15:10.1.1.eng: At that time there were monks who walked for alms with gourds as bowls.

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.3.eng: “They’re just like the monastics of other religions.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.5.eng: “You shouldn’t walk for alms with a gourd as a bowl.
pli-tv-kd15:10.1.5.comm: Sp 4.255: Tumbakaṭāhanti lābukaṭāhaṁ vuccati, “A gourd as a bowl is called a tumbakaṭāha.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū ghaṭikaṭāhe piṇḍāya caranti.
pli-tv-kd15:10.1.7.eng: At that time there were monks who walked for alms with waterpots as bowls.

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.9.eng: “They’re just like the monastics of other religions.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.11.eng: “You shouldn’t walk for alms with a waterpot as a bowl.

pli-tv-kd15:10.1.12.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu sabbapaṃsukūliko hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:10.2.1.eng: At that time a certain monk who only used discarded things

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.2.eng: used a skull as a bowl.

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.3.eng: A woman who saw this was terrified, screaming,

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.6.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā chavasīsassa pattaṃ dhāressanti, seyyathāpi pisācillikā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:10.2.6.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics use skulls as bowls? They’re just like goblins.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.8.eng: “You shouldn’t use a skull as a bowl.

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.9.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.10.eng: And you shouldn’t use only discarded things.

pli-tv-kd15:10.2.11.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū calakānipi aṭṭhikānipi ucchiṭṭhodakampi pattena nīharanti.
pli-tv-kd15:10.3.1.eng: At that time there were monks who carried away chewed food remnants, bones, and dirty mouth-rinsing water in their bowls.

pli-tv-kd15:10.3.3.pli: “yasmiṃ yevime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā bhuñjanti sova nesaṃ paṭiggaho”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:10.3.3.eng: “These Sakyan monastics use the vessel they’re eating from as a trash can.”

pli-tv-kd15:10.3.5.pli: “Na bhikkhave, calakāni vā aṭṭhikāni vā ucchiṭṭhodakaṃ vā pattena nīharitabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:10.3.5.eng: “You shouldn’t carry away chewed food remnants, bones, and dirty mouth-rinsing water in your almsbowl.

pli-tv-kd15:10.3.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū hatthena vipphāḷetvā cīvaraṃ sibbenti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.1.1.eng: At that time the monks tore cloth to pieces by hand and then sewed robes.

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.4.eng: “I allow a knife and a felt sheath.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa daṇḍasatthakaṃ uppannaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.1.5.eng: Soon afterwards the Sangha was offered a knife with a handle.

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.7.eng: “I allow a knife with a handle.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.8.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvace satthakadaṇḍe dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:11.1.8.eng: At this time the monks from the group of six used luxurious knife handles made with gold and silver.

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.10.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.13.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:11.1.14.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, aṭṭhimayaṃ dantamayaṃ visāṇamayaṃ naḷamayaṃ veḷumayaṃ kaṭṭhamayaṃ jatumayaṃ phalamayaṃ lohamayaṃ saṅkhanābhimayan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.1.14.eng: I allow knife handles made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, and shell.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.1.14.comm: “Made of fruit” renders phalamaya. In its discussion of ointment boxes, Khuddasikkhā-purāṇaṭīkā 185: Āmalakakakkādīhi katā phalamayā, “Made of fruit means made from ground emblic myrobalan, etc.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū kukkuṭapattenapi veḷupesikāyapi cīvaraṃ sibbenti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.2.1.eng: At that time the monks used chicken feathers and pieces of bamboo to sew robes.

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.6.eng: “I allow a cylinder for the needles.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.8.eng: “I allow you to fill them with yeast.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.2.8.comm: Sp 4.256: Kiṇṇena pūretunti kiṇṇacuṇṇena pūretuṁ, “To fill it with yeast means to fill it with yeast powder.’”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.10.eng: “I allow you to fill them with flour.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.12.comm: Sp 4.256: Saritakanti pāsāṇacuṇṇaṁ vuccati; tena pūretuṁ anujānāmīti attho, “Stone powder is called saritaka. The meaning is ‘I allow you to fill with that.’”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.14.eng: “I allow you to mix it with beeswax.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.2.14.comm: Sp 4.256: Madhusitthakena sāretunti madhusitthakena makkhetuṁ, “Madhusitthakena sāretuṁ means to mix with beeswax.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.15.comm: Sp 4.256: Saritakaṁ paribhijjatīti taṁ makkhitamadhusitthakaṁ bhijjati, “Saritakaṁ paribhijjati: that mixture with beeswax broke apart.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.2.16.comm: Sp 4.256: Saritasipāṭikanti madhusitthakapilotikaṁ; satthakosakasipāṭiyā pana saritasipāṭikāya anulomāti kurundiyaṁ vuttaṁ, “Saritasipāṭika: a piece of cloth with beeswax; but in the Kurundī it is said that a knife-sheath-sipāṭiyā is in conformity with a saritakasipāṭika.” At Kd 15:27.3.7 sipāṭika refers to a case (for a razor). I translate accordingly.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū tattha tattha khilaṃ nikkhaṇitvā sambandhitvā cīvaraṃ sibbenti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.1.eng: At that time the monks erected posts here and there, bound them together, and sewed robes.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.2.eng: The corners of the robes were deformed.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.4.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kathinaṃ kathinarajjuṃ tattha tattha obandhitvā cīvaraṃ sibbetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.4.eng: “I allow a frame and a string. You should tie down the cloth to the frame as required, before sewing the robe.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.4.comm: The word rendered as “frame” is kathina. See discussion of kathina in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.5.eng: They laid the frame on uneven ground.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.7.eng: “You shouldn’t lay the frame on uneven ground.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.9.eng: They laid the frame on the ground.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.12.eng: The edges of the frame deteriorated.

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.13.eng: “I allow you to add an edge lengthwise and crosswise.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.14.eng: The frame was not the right size.
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.14.comm: Sp 4.256: Kathinaṁ nappahotīti dīghassa bhikkhuno pamāṇena kataṁ kathinaṁ; tattha rassassa bhikkhuno cīvaraṁ patthariyamānaṁ nappahoti, antoyeva hoti; daṇḍake na pāpuṇātīti attho, “The frame was not the right size: the frame had been made to fit the size of a tall monk and it was not the right size for spreading out the robe-cloth for a short monk—it fell within; the meaning is the sticks (of the frame) are the wrong size.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.15.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, daṇḍakathinaṃ bidalakaṃ salākaṃ vinandhanarajjuṃ vinandhanasuttaṃ vinandhitvā cīvaraṃ sibbetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.15.eng: “I allow an inner frame, folding a straw mat to fit the frame, spacers, strings for tying together, and strings for tying down. After tying it together, you should sew the robe.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.15.comm: “An inner frame” renders daṇḍakathina. Sp 4.256: Daṇḍakathinanti tassa majjhe itarassa bhikkhuno pamāṇena aññaṁ nisseṇiṁ bandhituṁ anujānāmīti attho, “Daṇḍakathina: the meaning is ‘I allow you to bind another frame to fit the size of another monk in the middle of that (large frame).’” Sp 4.256: Bidalakanti daṇḍakathinappamāṇena kaṭasārakassa pariyante paṭisaṁharitvā duguṇakaraṇaṁ, “Bidalaka: making a double layer by folding the ends of a straw mat to fit the inner frame.” Sp 4.256: Salākanti dupaṭṭacīvarassa antare pavesanasalākaṁ, “Salāka: a salāka for inserting between a double-layer robe-cloth.” Sp 4.256: Vinandhanarajjunti mahānisseṇiyā saddhiṁ khuddakaṁ nisseṇiṁ vinandhituṁ rajjuṁ, “Vinandhanarajju: a string to tie the small frame to the large frame.” Sp 4.256: Vinandhanasuttanti khuddakanisseṇiyā cīvaraṁ vinandhituṁ suttakaṁ, “Vinandhanasutta: a string to tie the robe-cloth to the small frame.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.17.comm: Sp 4.256: Kaḷimbhakanti pamāṇasaññākaraṇaṁ yaṅkiñci tālapaṇṇādiṁ, “Kaḷimbhaka: whatever enables one to perceive the distance, (such as) a palmleaf, etc.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.3.19.eng: “I allow you to make a guide line.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.3.19.comm: Sp 4.256: Moghasuttakanti vaḍḍhakīnaṁ dārūsu kāḷasuttena viya haliddisuttena saññākaraṇaṁ, “Moghasuttaka: by means of a thread with turmeric, like the black thread on wood used by carpenters; what enables one to perceive.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū adhotehi pādehi kathinaṃ akkamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.4.1.eng: There were monks who stepped on the frame with dirty feet.

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.4.eng: “You shouldn’t step on the frame with dirty feet.

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.5.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū allehi pādehi kathinaṃ akkamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.4.6.eng: There were monks who stepped on the frame with wet feet.

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.9.eng: “You shouldn’t step on the frame with wet feet.

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.11.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū saupāhanā kathinaṃ akkamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.4.11.eng: There were monks who stepped on the frame while wearing sandals.

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.14.eng: “You shouldn’t step on the frame while wearing sandals.

pli-tv-kd15:11.4.15.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū cīvaraṃ sibbantā aṅguliyā paṭiggaṇhanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.5.1.eng: When sewing robes, the monks used their bare fingers.

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvace paṭiggahe dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:11.5.5.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six used luxurious thimbles made with gold and silver.

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.7.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.11.eng: I allow a thimble made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal,

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sūciyopi satthakāpi paṭiggahāpi nassanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.5.13.eng: Needles, knives, and thimbles got lost.

pli-tv-kd15:11.5.21.eng: “I allow a shoulder strap and a string for fastening.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū abbhokāse cīvaraṃ sibbantā sītenapi uṇhenapi kilamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.6.1.eng: When sewing robes outside, the monks were troubled by the cold and heat.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.3.eng: “I allow sewing sheds and roof covers.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.6.3.comm: For an explanation of rendering sālā as “shed”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.4.eng: They built the sewing shed on a low base. It was flooded.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.6.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.8.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.9.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.10.eng: It was difficult to get up to the sewing sheds.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.12.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.13.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.15.eng: Grass and dust fell into the sewing sheds.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.16.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then plaster it inside and outside, including:
pli-tv-kd15:11.6.16.comm: “To firm up the structure” renders ogumphetvā. Sp 4.257: Ogumphetvā ullittāvalittaṁ kātunti chadanaṁ odhunitvā ghanadaṇḍakaṁ katvā anto ceva bahi ca mattikāya limpitunti attho, “Ogumphetvā ullittāvalittaṁ kātuṁ: having shook out the roof cover and added rods to firm up (the structure), to smear with clay inside and outside—this is the meaning.” At Kd 5:11.1.5 the same verb, in the form ogumphiyanti, is used to show how dwellings are “held together” by straps of leather. This makes it certain that ogumphetvā in the present context must refer to the “firming up” rather than the “shaking out”.

pli-tv-kd15:11.6.17.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ cīvaravaṃsaṃ cīvararajjukan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.6.17.eng: treating it with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern; putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”
pli-tv-kd15:11.6.17.comm: “The fivefold pattern” renders pañcapaṭika. Vmv 4.299: Pāḷiyaṁ pañcapaṭikanti jātiādipañcappakāravaṇṇamaṭṭhaṁ, “Pañcapaṭika in the canonical text means the five-fold appearance, starting with jasmine.” The meaning is not clear.

pli-tv-kd15:11.7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū cīvaraṃ sibbetvā tattheva kathinaṃ ujjhitvā pakkamanti, undūrehipi upacikāhipi khajjati.
pli-tv-kd15:11.7.1.eng: At that time, when they had finished sewing a robe, there were monks who abandoned the frame right there and left. Rats and termites ate it.

pli-tv-kd15:11.7.5.eng: “You should fold it up with a rod for support.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.7.7.eng: “You should tie it up with a rope.”

pli-tv-kd15:11.7.8.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū kuṭṭepi thambhepi kathinaṃ ussāpetvā pakkamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.7.8.eng: At that time there were monks who leaned the frame against a wall or a pillar and left.

pli-tv-kd15:11.7.11.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, bhittikhile vā nāgadante vā laggetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:11.7.11.eng: “You should hang it from a wall peg.”

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahe yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena vesālī tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd15:12.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Vesālī.

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū sūcikampi satthakampi bhesajjampi pattena ādāya gacchanti.
pli-tv-kd15:12.1.2.eng: And so did the monks, having put their needles, knives, and medicines in their almsbowls.

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.6.eng: “I allow a shoulder strap and a string for fastening it.”

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu upāhanāyo kāyabandhanena bandhitvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
pli-tv-kd15:12.1.7.eng: On one occasion a certain monk bound his sandals to his belt and entered the village for alms.

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.8.pli: Aññataro upāsako taṃ bhikkhuṃ abhivādento upāhanāyo sīsena ghaṭṭeti.
pli-tv-kd15:12.1.8.eng: A lay follower who bowed to him hit his head against those sandals.

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.10.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd15:12.1.10.eng: When he had returned to the monastery, he told the monks what had happened,

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.11.eng: who in turn told the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd15:12.1.14.eng: “I allow a shoulder strap and a string for fastening it.”

pli-tv-kd15:13.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena antarāmagge udakaṃ akappiyaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:13.1.1.eng: While they were traveling, there was only unallowable water,
pli-tv-kd15:13.1.1.comm: Vmv 4.258: Udakaṁ akappiyanti sappāṇakaṁ, “Unallowable water: it contained living beings.”

pli-tv-kd15:13.1.6.eng: “I allow a filter with a handle.”

pli-tv-kd15:13.1.7.eng: There was still no suitable cloth.

pli-tv-kd15:13.1.8.comm: It is not clear how the “water strainer”, dhammakaraṇa, is different from the “water filter”, arissāvana. The commentaries are silent.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dve bhikkhū kosalesu janapade addhānamaggappaṭipannā honti.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.1.eng: On one occasion, there were two monks traveling through the Kosalan country.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.3.eng: and the second monk said to him,

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.6.eng: Because of that, the first monk became resentful.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.7.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu pipāsāya pīḷito upanaddhaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.7.eng: Soon afterwards the second monk was very thirsty. He asked the resentful monk

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.10.eng: and the second monk died from thirst.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.11.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.11.eng: When the resentful monk arrived at the monastery, he told the monks what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.12.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, āvuso, parissāvanaṃ yāciyamāno na adāsī”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.12.eng: “So you refused to lend your water filter when asked?”

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.14.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.14.eng: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.15.pli: “kathañhi nāma bhikkhu parissāvanaṃ yāciyamāno na dassatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.15.eng: “How could a monk do such a thing?”

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.16.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.17.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ paṭipucchi—
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.17.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the monks gathered and questioned that monk:

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.18.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, bhikkhu, parissāvanaṃ yāciyamāno na adāsī”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.18.eng: “Is it true, monk, that you did this?”

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.21.pli: “ananucchavikaṃ, moghapurisa, ananulomikaṃ appatirūpaṃ assāmaṇakaṃ akappiyaṃ akaraṇīyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.21.eng: “It’s not suitable, foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of a monastic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.22.pli: Kathañhi nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, parissāvanaṃ yāciyamāno na dassasi.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.22.eng: How could you refuse to lend your water filter when asked?

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.25.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.26.pli: “na, bhikkhave, addhānamaggappaṭipannena bhikkhunā parissāvanaṃ yāciyamānena na dātabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.26.eng: “If you’re traveling with a monk and he asks to borrow your water filter, you should lend it.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.27.eng: If you don’t, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.28.pli: Na ca, bhikkhave, aparissāvanakena addhāno paṭipajjitabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.28.eng: On the other hand, you shouldn’t travel without a water filter.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.29.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:13.2.30.pli: Sace na hoti parissāvanaṃ vā dhammakaraṇo vā, saṅghāṭikaṇṇopi adhiṭṭhātabbo—
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.30.eng: If there’s no water filter or strainer, you should determine a corner of your robe:
pli-tv-kd15:13.2.30.comm: For an explanation of rendering saṅghāṭi as “robe”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena vesālī tadavasari.
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.1.eng: The Buddha eventually arrived at Vesālī

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.2.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.2.eng: where he stayed in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū navakammaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.3.eng: At this time the monks were doing building work,

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.4.eng: but there were not enough water filters.
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.4.comm: Sp-ṭ 4.259: Na sammatīti nappahoti, “Na sammati: not enough.”

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.6.eng: “I allow a water filter of cloth fitted to a wooden framework.”
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.6.comm: Sp 4.259: Daṇḍaparissāvananti rajakānaṁ khāraparissāvanaṁ viya catūsu pādesu baddhanisseṇikāya sāṭakaṁ bandhitvā majjhedaṇḍake udakaṁ āsiñcitabbaṁ, taṁ ubhopi koṭṭhāse pūretvā parissavati, “Daṇḍaparissāvana: like the filters for caustic substances used by dyers, having bound a cloth to a framework fastened on four legs, the water is filtered by pouring on the middle rod, having filled on both sides.”

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.7.eng: There were still not enough filters.

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.9.eng: “I allow you to filter by spreading cloth on water.”
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.9.comm: Sp 4.259: Ottharakaṁ nāma yaṁ udake ottharitvā ghaṭakena udakaṁ gaṇhanti, tañhi catūsu daṇḍakesu vatthaṁ bandhitvā udake cattāro khāṇuke nikhaṇitvā tesu bandhitvā sabbapariyante udakato mocetvā majjhe ottharitvā ghaṭena udakaṁ gaṇhanti, “Ottharaka: having spread it on water, they collect water with a jar. That is, having bound a cloth onto four rods, having implanted four stakes in the water, having bound them together, keeping it out of the water on all sides, having spread it out (in the water) in the middle, they collect water with a jar.”

pli-tv-kd15:13.3.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū makasehi ubbāḷhā honti.
pli-tv-kd15:13.3.10.eng: At this time the monks were troubled by mosquitoes.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vesāliyaṃ paṇītānaṃ bhattānaṃ bhattapaṭipāṭi aṭṭhitā hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.1.eng: At this time in Vesālī people had arranged a succession of fine meals.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.2.pli: Bhikkhū paṇītāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā abhisannakāyā honti bahvābādhā.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.2.eng: After eating the fine food, the monks were often sick, their bodies being full of impurities.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.3.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco vesāliṃ agamāsi kenacideva karaṇīyena.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.3.eng: Just then Jīvaka Komārabhacca was in Vesālī on some business,

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.4.pli: Addasā kho jīvako komārabhacco bhikkhū abhisannakāye bahvābādhe.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.5.pli: Disvāna yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.5.eng: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.6.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.7.eng: “At present, sir, there are monks who are often sick, their bodies being full of impurities.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.8.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā bhikkhūnaṃ caṅkamañca jantāgharañca anujānātu.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.8.eng: Please allow walking-meditation paths and saunas.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.9.eng: In this way the monks will rarely get sick.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.10.pli: Atha kho bhagavā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.10.eng: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching,

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.11.pli: Atha kho jīvako komārabhacco bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.11.eng: after which Jīvaka got up from his seat, bowed, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.12.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd15:14.1.12.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:14.1.13.comm: For an explanation of rendering jantāghara as “sauna”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū visame caṅkame caṅkamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.2.1.eng: Monks did walking meditation on uneven walking paths.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.2.eng: As a result their feet hurt.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.4.eng: “I allow you to even them out.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.5.eng: They built walking-meditation paths on a low base.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.7.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.9.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.10.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.11.eng: It was difficult to get up on the walking-meditation paths.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.13.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.14.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.16.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū caṅkame caṅkamantā paripatanti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.2.16.eng: Monks fell off while doing walking meditation.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.19.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū ajjhokāse caṅkamantā sītenapi uṇhenapi kilamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.2.19.eng: Doing walking meditation outside, monks were troubled by the cold and the heat.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.21.comm: For a discussion of sālā, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.22.eng: Grass and dust fell into the indoor walking-meditation paths.

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.23.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd15:14.2.24.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ cīvaravaṃsaṃ cīvararajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.2.24.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern; putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.1.eng: They built saunas on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.2.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.4.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.5.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.6.eng: It was difficult to get up to the saunas.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.8.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.9.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.12.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kavāṭaṃ piṭṭhasaṅghāṭaṃ udukkhalikaṃ uttarapāsakaṃ aggaḷavaṭṭiṃ kapisīsakaṃ sūcikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ tāḷacchiddaṃ āviñchanachiddaṃ āviñchanarajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.12.eng: “I allow doors, door frames, lower hinges, upper hinges, door jambs, bolt sockets, bolts, latches, keyholes, door-pulling holes, and door-pulling ropes.”
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.12.comm: “A lower hinge” renders udukkhalika, while “an upper hinge” is for uttarapāsaka. Sp 1.77: … yena kenaci kavāṭaṁ katvā heṭṭhā udukkhale upari uttarapāsake ca pavesetvā kataṁ parivattakadvārameva saṁvaritabbaṁ … atha dvārassa udukkhalaṁ vā uttarapāsako vā bhinno vā hoti aṭṭhapito vā, saṁvarituṁ na sakkoti, “Having made a door by whatever (material), having entered it into the udukkhala below and into the uttarapāsaka above, it is made a revolving door to be closed … but when the udukkhala or the uttarapāsaka is broken or not mounted, then one cannot close the door.” From this it seems that the udukkhala and uttarapāsaka, together with the two corresponding “projecting pivots” on the door, are the functional equivalents of hinges. Udukkhalika and udukkhala refer to the same thing, the former being used in the canonical text, whereas the latter is found in the summary verses. For further details see CPD, sv. uttarapāsaka. “Door jambs” renders aggaḷavaṭṭi. Sp 4.260: Aggaḷavaṭṭi nāma dvārabāhāya samappamāṇoyeva aggaḷatthambho vuccati, yattha tīṇi cattāri chiddāni katvā sūciyo denti, “Aggaḷavaṭṭi: it is called a door post, which is the same length as the door frame. It is where three or four holes are made for inserting bolts.” Whenever the Canonical text lists the parts of a door and door frame, the aggaḷavaṭṭi always has the same position, being grouped together with the parts for the locking mechanism, such as latches and bolts. Given the commentarial explanation, it is natural to think that it was a special post added to the door frame, or perhaps replacing the door frame, for the purpose of receiving bolts. “Bolt socket” renders kapisīsaka. Sp 4.260: Kapisīsakaṁ nāma dvārabāhaṁ vijjhitvā tattha pavesito aggaḷapāsako vuccati, “The bolt-receiving socket which is inserted after piercing the door post is called a kapisīsaka.” “Bolt” renders sūcika. Sp 4.260: Sūcikāti tattha majjhe chiddaṁ katvā pavesitā, “It is entered, having made a hole in the middle there.” Vmv 4.260: Tattha majjheti aggaḷapāsakassa majjhe, “In the middle there: in the middle of the door jamb.” “Latch” renders ghaṭika. Sp-ṭ 4.255: Ghaṭikanti upari yojitaṁ aggaḷaṁ, “Ghaṭika: it connected the door at the top.” From the origin story of Bu Ss 2:1.1.11 it seems that the ghaṭika was a device that could be opened with a key: Avāpuraṇaṁ ādāya ghaṭikaṁ ugghāṭetvā kavāṭaṁ paṇāmetvā vihāraṁ pāvisi, “(Udāyī) took the key, lifted the latch, opened the door, and entered the dwelling.” It follows from this that the ghaṭika is unlikely to be a bolt, but probably a kind of bar, like a latch, that would require lifting for the door to open. The lifting would be done with tāḷa, a key-like device. “A door-pulling hole” renders āviñchanachidda. Vmv 4.296: Āviñchanachiddanti yattha aṅguliṁ vā rajjusaṅkhalikādiṁ vā pavesetvā kavāṭaṁ ākaḍḍhantā dvārabāhaṁ phusāpenti, “Āviñchanachidda: where, having entered the finger or a rope or a chain, etc., they pull the door and make it touch the door post.” “A door-pulling rope” renders āviñchanarajju. Sp 4.296: Āviñchanarajjunti kavāṭeyeva chiddaṁ katvā tattha pavesetvā yena rajjukena kaḍḍhantā dvāraṁ phusāpenti, “Having made a hole in the door, having entered (the rope) there, the rope with which they close and make the door touch (the post).” For a discussion of the aggaḷa as “door”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.13.eng: The base of the sauna walls deteriorated.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.14.eng: “I allow you to make encircling trenches.”
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.14.comm: Sp 4.260: Maṇḍalikaṁ kātunti nīcavatthukaṁ cinituṁ, “To make a maṇḍalika means to construct a low site.” Sp-ṭ 4.260: Nīcavatthukaṁ cinitunti bahikuṭṭassa samantato nīcavatthukaṁ katvā cinituṁ, “Nīcavatthukaṁ cinituṁ means to construct after making the ground low on all sides outside the wall.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū khuddake jantāghare majjhe aggiṭṭhānaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.17.eng: At that time the monks built a fireplace in the middle of a small sauna.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.18.eng: There was no access around the fireplace.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.20.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, khuddake jantāghare ekamantaṃ aggiṭṭhānaṃ kātuṃ, mahallake majjhe”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.20.eng: “In a small sauna, you should make the fireplace to one side, but in a large one in the middle.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.21.eng: The fire in the sauna scorched their faces.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.23.eng: They moistened the clay in their hands.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.24.eng: “I allow a trough for the clay.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.27.eng: The fire in the sauna scorched their bodies.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.29.eng: They brought the water in basins and bowls.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.30.eng: “I allow a place for the water and a water scoop.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.31.eng: Because the sauna had a grass roof, they did not sweat.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.32.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.35.eng: floors of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.40.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū jantāghare chamāya nisīdanti, gattāni kaṇḍūvanti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.40.eng: The monks sat on the ground and their limbs became itchy.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.43.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jantāgharaṃ aparikkhittaṃ hoti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:14.3.43.eng: At that time the saunas were unenclosed.

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.44.eng: “I allow three kinds of encircling walls:

pli-tv-kd15:14.3.45.eng: walls of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.1.comm: For the rendering “gatehouse” for koṭṭhaka, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.3.eng: They built the gatehouses on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.4.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.6.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations:

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.7.eng: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.8.eng: It was difficult to get up to the gatehouses.

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.10.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.11.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.14.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, kavāṭaṃ piṭṭhasaṅghāṭaṃ udukkhalikaṃ uttarapāsakaṃ aggaḷavaṭṭiṃ kapisīsakaṃ sūcikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ tāḷacchiddaṃ āviñchanachiddaṃ āviñchanarajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:14.4.14.eng: “I allow doors, door frames, lower hinges, upper hinges, door jambs, bolt sockets, bolts, latches, keyholes, door-pulling holes, and door-pulling ropes.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.15.eng: Grass and dust fell into the gatehouses.

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.16.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd15:14.4.17.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikan”ti.
