pli-tv-kd15:14.4.17.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.5.1.comm: For an explanation of rendering pariveṇa as “yard”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:14.5.2.eng: “I allow a you to cover them with gravel.”

pli-tv-kd15:14.5.3.eng: They were unable to do it.
pli-tv-kd15:14.5.3.comm: This is an unusual use of the verb pariyāpuṇati, which normally means “to learn”. I follow the suggestion in DOP.

pli-tv-kd15:14.5.4.eng: “I allow you to lay paving stones.”
pli-tv-kd15:14.5.4.comm: Or “slabs of stone”, padarasila. See Bu Pc 18:2.3.5 where padara means “floor boards”.

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū naggā naggaṃ abhivādenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:15.1.1.eng: At that time naked monks bowed down to other naked monks,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.2.pli: naggā naggaṃ abhivādāpenti, naggā naggassa parikammaṃ karonti, naggā naggassa parikammaṃ kārāpenti, naggā naggassa denti, naggā paṭiggaṇhanti, naggā khādanti, naggā bhuñjanti, naggā sāyanti, naggā pivanti.
pli-tv-kd15:15.1.2.eng: had other naked monks bow down to them, provided assistance to other naked monks, had other naked monks provide assistance to them, gave to other naked monks, received, ate fresh foods, ate cooked foods, ate other foods, and drank.

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.4.eng: “One who is naked shouldn’t bow down to one who is naked,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.6.eng: shouldn’t have a naked monk bow down to him,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.7.eng: shouldn’t have anyone bow down to him,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.8.eng: shouldn’t provide assistance to a naked monk,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.9.eng: shouldn’t have a naked monk provide assistance to him,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.10.eng: shouldn’t give to a naked monk,

pli-tv-kd15:15.1.16.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū jantāghare chamāya cīvaraṃ nikkhipanti.
pli-tv-kd15:16.1.1.eng: At that time the monks put their robes on the ground in the sauna.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.4.eng: “I allow bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.5.eng: It rained and the robes became wet.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.6.comm: “Sauna shed” renders jantāgharasālā. It seems from the above description of a sauna that it was a building, including a roof. A jantāgharasālā is then presumably another building (from the description below it seems to be a separate building from the sauna) where you get undressed and hang up your robes, etc. For an explanation of rendering sālā as “shed”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.7.eng: They built the sauna sheds on a low base. They were flooded.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.8.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.10.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.11.1.eng: It was difficult to get up to the sauna sheds.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.11.2.eng: “I allow three kinds of stairs: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.12.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.14.eng: Grass and dust fell into the sauna sheds.

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.15.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then to plaster it inside and outside, including: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern;

pli-tv-kd15:16.1.16.eng: putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū jantāgharepi udakepi parikammaṃ kātuṃ kukkuccāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.1.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not provide assistance to one another either in the sauna or in the water.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.3.eng: “I allow you to regard three things as a ‘covering’:

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.4.eng: a sauna, water, and a cloth.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jantāghare udakaṃ na hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.5.1.eng: On one occasion there was no water in the sauna.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.8.eng: The edge of the well collapsed.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.9.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of foundations:

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.10.eng: foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.11.eng: The well was situated at a low point. It was flooded.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.12.eng: “I allow you to raise the base.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.13.2.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of raised foundations: raised foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.14.1.eng: It was difficult to get up to the well.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.14.2.eng: “I allow three kinds of stairs: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.15.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū vallikāyapi kāyabandhanenapi udakaṃ vāhenti.
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.17.eng: At that time the monks used creepers and belts to haul water.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.21.eng: “I allow a well-sweep, a pulley, and well-wheels.”
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.21.comm: “Well-sweep”, “pulley”, and “well-wheels” respectively render tula, karakaṭaka, and cakkavaṭṭaka. For all three words see CPD, sv. karakaṭaka.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.24.eng: buckets made of iron, wood, and hide.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.25.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū ajjhokāse udakaṃ vāhentā sītenapi uṇhenapi kilamanti.
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.25.eng: Hauling water outside, the monks were troubled by the cold and the heat.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.27.comm: For an explanation of rendering sālā as “house”, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.28.eng: Grass and dust fell into the well houses.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.29.eng: “I allow you to firm up the structure and then plaster it inside and outside, including:

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.30.pli: setavaṇṇaṃ kāḷavaṇṇaṃ gerukaparikammaṃ mālākammaṃ latākammaṃ makaradantakaṃ pañcapaṭikaṃ cīvaravaṃsaṃ cīvararajjun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.30.eng: treating with white color, black color, and red ocher; making garland patterns, creeper patterns, shark-teeth patterns, and the fivefold pattern; putting up bamboo robe racks and clotheslines.”

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.31.pli: Udapāno apāruto hoti, tiṇacuṇṇehipi paṃsukehipi okiriyyati …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:16.2.31.eng: The wells were not covered. Grass, dust, and dirt fell into them.

pli-tv-kd15:16.2.33.eng: There were no vessels for the water.

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū ārāme tahaṃ tahaṃ nahāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:17.1.1.eng: At that time the monks bathed here and there in the monastery.

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.4.comm: “Waste-water disposal area” renders candanika, which is not defined in the Vinaya commentaries. Elsewhere, however, we find the following definition, e.g. at MN-a 1.25: Candanikanti ucchiṭṭhodakagabbhamalādīnaṁ chaḍḍanaṭṭhānaṁ, “Candanika means a place for the discarding of used water, afterbirth, etc.” We also know that it is not a cesspit, which is known as a vaccakūpa, see below.

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.5.comm: Sp 4.262: Pākaṭā hotīti aparikkhittā hoti, “Pākaṭā hoti means it is unenclosed.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.6.eng: The monks were embarrassed to bathe there.

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.7.eng: “I allow three kinds of encircling walls:

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.8.eng: walls of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.11.eng: deckings of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.14.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhūnaṃ gattāni sītigatāni honti.

pli-tv-kd15:17.1.16.eng: “I allow a water wiper and a towel to dry yourselves.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro upāsako saṅghassa atthāya pokkharaṇiṃ kāretukāmo hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:17.2.1.eng: On one occasion a lay follower wanted to build a lotus bathing tank for the benefit of the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd15:17.2.1.comm: For an explanation of the rendering “lotus bathing tank” for pokkharaṇī, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.4.eng: The edges of the tank collapsed.

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.5.eng: “I allow you to construct three kinds of foundations:

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.6.eng: foundations of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.7.eng: It was difficult to get up to the tank.

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.9.eng: stairs of brick, stone, and wood.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.10.eng: People fell down while climbing the stairs.

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.12.eng: The water in the tanks became stagnant.

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.13.eng: “I allow a channel and a drain.”

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.14.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu saṅghassa atthāya nillekhaṃ jantāgharaṃ kattukāmo hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:17.2.14.eng: On one occasion a certain monk wanted to build a sauna with a pointed roof for the benefit of the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:17.2.16.comm: “Saunas with pointed roofs” renders nillekhaṁ jantāgharaṁ. Sp 4.263: Nillekhajantāgharaṁ nāma āviddhapakkhapāsakaṁ vuccati, gopānasīnaṁ upari maṇḍale pakkhapāsake ṭhapetvā katakūṭacchadanassetaṁ nāmaṁ, “One with a side loop all around is called a nillekhajantāghara. Having fixed on a side loop circle above the rafters, this is a name for a roof made with a peak.” The exact meaning is not clear to me.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.0.eng: Various regulations on proper conduct and allowable requisites

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū cātumāsaṃ nisīdanena vippavasanti.
pli-tv-kd15:18.1.1.eng: At one time the monks from the group of six did not have sitting mats for a period of four months.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.3.eng: “You shouldn’t be without a sitting mat for a period of four months.
pli-tv-kd15:18.1.3.comm: For an explanation of the rendering “sitting mat” for nisīdana, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.4.eng: If you are, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū pupphābhikiṇṇesu sayanesu sayanti.
pli-tv-kd15:18.1.5.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six slept in beds covered in flowers.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.6.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd15:18.1.6.eng: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.7.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.9.eng: “You shouldn’t sleep in a bed covered in flowers.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.10.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.11.pli: Tena kho pana samayena manussā gandhampi mālampi ādāya ārāmaṃ āgacchanti.
pli-tv-kd15:18.1.11.eng: Soon, people brought scents and garlands to the monastery.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.12.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept.

pli-tv-kd15:18.1.14.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, gandhaṃ gahetvā kavāṭe pañcaṅgulikaṃ dātuṃ, pupphaṃ gahetvā vihāre ekamantaṃ nikkhipitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:18.1.14.eng: “I allow you to accept scent to make the five-finger mark on your door and to accept flowers to place to one side in your dwelling.”

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa namatakaṃ uppannaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:19.1.1.eng: On one occasion the Sangha was offered a piece of felt.

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.5.eng: “Should it be determined or assigned to another?”

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.6.eng: “It should neither be determined nor assigned to another.”
pli-tv-kd15:19.1.6.comm: For an explanation of the idea of vikappanā, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū āsittakūpadhāne bhuñjanti.
pli-tv-kd15:19.1.7.eng: The monks from the group of six ate food on a stand with a heating device.
pli-tv-kd15:19.1.7.comm: Sp 4.264: Āsittakūpadhānaṁ nāma tambalohena vā rajatena vā katāya peḷāya etaṁ adhivacanaṁ, paṭikkhittattā pana dārumayāpi na vaṭṭati, “Āsittakūpadhāna: this is a term for a container made of copper or silver. But a prohibited one made of wood is also not allowable.” Vmv 4.264: Peḷāyāti aṭṭhaṁsasoḷasaṁsādiākārena katāya bhājanākārāya peḷāya. Yattha uṇhapāyāsādiṁ pakkhipitvā upari bhojanapātiṁ ṭhapenti bhattassa uṇhabhāvāvigamanatthaṁ, tādisassa bhājanākārassa ādhārassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ. Teneva pāḷiyaṁ āsittakūpadhānanti vuttaṁ, “Pelāya: a container having the form of a vessel made with eight or sixteen edges, etc., where, for the purpose of keeping the food hot, having filled with hot milk-rice, etc., they place a bowl with food on top. This is a term for the stand for such a vessel. For this reason it is said āsittakūpadhāna in the Canonical text.”

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.9.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.11.eng: “You shouldn’t eat food on a stand with a heating device.

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.12.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu gilāno hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:19.1.13.eng: On one occasion a certain sick monk

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.14.pli: So bhuñjamāno na sakkoti hatthena pattaṃ sandhāretuṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:19.1.14.eng: was unable to hold his bowl with his hands while eating.

pli-tv-kd15:19.1.16.comm: Sp-ṭ 4.264: Pubbe pattasaṅgopanatthaṁ ādhārako anuññāto, idāni bhuñjanatthaṁ, “Previously a stand for the purpose of protecting the bowls was allowed; now (it is allowed) for the purpose of eating.” The stand referred to here was allowed above at Kd 15:9.4.4 (there rendered as “rack”).

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū ekabhājanepi bhuñjanti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:19.2.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six ate from the same vessel and

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.2.pli: ekathālakepi pivanti, ekamañcepi tuvaṭṭenti, ekattharaṇāpi tuvaṭṭenti, ekapāvuraṇāpi tuvaṭṭenti, ekattharaṇapāvuraṇāpi tuvaṭṭenti.
pli-tv-kd15:19.2.2.eng: drank from the same vessel, and they lay down on the same bed, on the same sheet, under the same cover, and both on the same sheet and under the same cover.
pli-tv-kd15:19.2.2.comm: “The same sheet and under the same cover” renders ekattharaṇapāvuraṇa. Sp 2.937: Ekattharaṇapāvuraṇā; saṁhārimānaṁ pāvārattharaṇakaṭasārakādīnaṁ ekaṁ antaṁ attharitvā ekaṁ pārupitvā tuvaṭṭentīnametaṁ adhivacanaṁ, “Ekattharaṇapāvuraṇa: this is an expression for: a mobile blanket, a mat, a straw mat, etc., having spread one of these to one side and having covered with another, one lies down.”

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.4.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.6.eng: “You shouldn’t eat from the same vessel,

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.8.eng: lie down on the same bed,

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.9.eng: lie down on the same sheet,

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.10.eng: lie down under the same cover,

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.11.eng: or lie down both on the same sheet and under the same cover.

pli-tv-kd15:19.2.12.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vaḍḍho licchavī mettiyabhūmajakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sahāyo hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.1.eng: At one time Vaḍḍha the Licchavī was a friend of the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka.

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.2.pli: Atha kho vaḍḍho licchavī yena mettiyabhūmajakā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā mettiyabhūmajake bhikkhū etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.2.eng: On one occasion he went to them and said,

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho vaḍḍho licchavī mettiyabhūmajake bhikkhū etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.8.pli: Tatiyampi kho vaḍḍho licchavī mettiyabhūmajake bhikkhū etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.8.eng: and a third time he said the same thing,

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.10.eng: but they still did not respond.

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.11.pli: “Kyāhaṃ ayyānaṃ aparajjhāmi, kissa maṃ ayyā nālapantī”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.11.eng: “Have I done something wrong? Why don’t you respond?”

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.12.pli: “Tathā hi pana tvaṃ, āvuso vaḍḍha, amhe dabbena mallaputtena viheṭhiyamāne ajjhupekkhasī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.12.eng: “It’s because we’ve been treated badly by Dabba the Mallian, and you’re not taking an interest.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.14.pli: “Sace kho tvaṃ, āvuso vaḍḍha, iccheyyāsi, ajjeva bhagavā āyasmantaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ nāsāpeyyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.14.eng: “If you like, you could make the Buddha expel Dabba.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.15.pli: “Kyāhaṃ, ayyā, karomi, kiṃ mayā sakkā kātun”ti?

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.16.pli: “Ehi tvaṃ, āvuso vaḍḍha, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ evaṃ vadehi—

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.17.eng: ‘Sir, this is not proper or appropriate.

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.18.pli: Yāyaṃ, bhante, disā abhayā anītikā anupaddavā sāyaṃ disā sabhayā saītikā saupaddavā;
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.18.eng: There’s fear, distress, and oppression in this district, where none of these should exist.

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.19.eng: It’s windy where it should be calm.

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.20.eng: It’s as if water is burning.

pli-tv-kd15:20.1.21.pli: ayyena me dabbena mallaputtena pajāpati dūsitā’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.1.21.eng: Venerable Dabba the Mallian has raped my wife.’”

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.1.pli: “Evaṃ, ayyā”ti kho vaḍḍho licchavī mettiyabhūmajakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd15:20.2.1.eng: Saying, “Alright, venerables,” he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vaḍḍho licchavī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.3.eng: what he had been told to say.

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.4.pli: Yāyaṃ, bhante, disā abhayā anītikā anupaddavā sāyaṃ disā sabhayā saītikā saupaddavā;

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.7.pli: ayyena me dabbena mallaputtena pajāpati dūsitā”ti.

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.8.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā āyasmantaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ paṭipucchi—
pli-tv-kd15:20.2.8.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned Dabba:

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.9.pli: “sarasi tvaṃ, dabba, evarūpaṃ kattā yathāyaṃ vaḍḍho āhā”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:20.2.9.eng: “Dabba, do you remember doing as Vaḍḍha says?”

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.12.pli: tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:20.2.12.eng: and a third time the Buddha asked the same question

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.13.pli: “sarasi tvaṃ, dabba, evarūpaṃ kattā yathāyaṃ vaḍḍho āhā”ti?

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.15.eng: He then said, “Dabba, the Dabbas don’t give such evasive answers.

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.16.eng: If it was done by you, say so;

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.17.eng: if it wasn’t, then say that.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.2.18.pli: “Yato ahaṃ, bhante, jāto nābhijānāmi supinantenapi methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevitā, pageva jāgaro”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.2.18.eng: “Since I was born, sir, I don’t recall having sexual intercourse even in a dream, let alone when awake.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.3.2.pli: “tena hi, bhikkhave, saṅgho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattaṃ nikkujjatu, asambhogaṃ saṅghena karotu.
pli-tv-kd15:20.3.2.eng: “Well then, monks, the Sangha should overturn the almsbowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.3.3.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatassa upāsakassa patto nikkujjitabbo—
pli-tv-kd15:20.3.3.eng: When a lay follower has eight qualities, you should overturn your bowl against him:

pli-tv-kd15:20.3.4.pli: bhikkhūnaṃ alābhāya parisakkati, bhikkhūnaṃ anatthāya parisakkati, bhikkhūnaṃ avāsāya parisakkati, bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati, bhikkhū bhikkhūhi bhedeti, buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
pli-tv-kd15:20.3.4.eng: he’s trying to stop monks from getting material support; he’s trying to harm monks; he’s trying to get monks to lose their place of residence; he abuses and reviles monks; he causes division between monks; he disparages the Buddha; he disparages the Teaching; he disparages the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.3.5.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imehi aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgatassa upāsakassa pattaṃ nikkujjituṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.1.eng: And the overturning of the bowl is to be done like this.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.2.eng: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.3.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.4.pli: Vaḍḍho licchavī āyasmantaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ amūlikāya sīlavipattiyā anuddhaṃseti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.4.eng: Vaḍḍha the Licchavī is groundlessly charging Venerable Dabba the Mallian with failure in morality.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.5.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattaṃ nikkujjeyya, asambhogaṃ saṅghena kareyya.
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.5.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should overturn the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.7.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.8.pli: Vaḍḍho licchavī āyasmantaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ amūlikāya sīlavipattiyā anuddhaṃseti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.8.eng: Vaḍḍha the Licchavī is groundlessly charging Venerable Dabba the Mallian with failure in morality.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.9.pli: Saṅgho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattaṃ nikkujjati, asambhogaṃ saṅghena karoti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.9.eng: The Sangha overturns the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.10.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattassa nikkujjanā, asambhogaṃ saṅghena karaṇaṃ, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.10.eng: Any monk who approves of overturning the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.11.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.12.pli: Nikkujjito saṅghena vaḍḍhassa licchavissa patto, asambhogo saṅghena.
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.12.eng: The Sangha has overturned the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.4.13.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.4.13.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena vaḍḍhassa licchavissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā vaḍḍhaṃ licchaviṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.1.eng: After robing up the following morning, Venerable Ānanda took his bowl and robe, went to the house of Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, and told him,

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.2.eng: “Vaḍḍha, the Sangha has overturned the bowl against you.

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.3.eng: You’re prohibited from interacting with the Sangha.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.5.pli: saṅghena kira me patto nikkujjito, asambhogomhi kira saṅghenāti—

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.7.pli: Atha kho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā vaḍḍhaṃ licchaviṃ etadavocuṃ—
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.7.eng: But Vaḍḍha’s friends and relatives said to him,

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.8.pli: “alaṃ, āvuso vaḍḍha, mā soci, mā paridevi.

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.9.eng: We’ll reconcile you with the Buddha and the Sangha of monks.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.10.pli: Atha kho vaḍḍho licchavī saputtadāro samittāmacco sañātisālohito allavattho allakeso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.10.eng: Soon afterwards Vaḍḍha, together with his wives and children, together with his friends and relatives, with wet clothes and wet hair, went to the Buddha. He bowed down at the Buddha’s feet and said,

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.11.pli: “accayo maṃ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yohaṃ ayyaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ amūlikāya sīlavipattiyā anuddhaṃsesiṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.11.eng: “Sir, I’ve made a mistake. I’ve been foolish, confused, and unskillful.

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.12.pli: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā accayaṃ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṃ saṃvarāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.12.eng: Please forgive me so that I may restrain myself in the future.”

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.13.pli: “Taggha tvaṃ, āvuso vaḍḍha, accayo accagamā yathābālaṃ yathāmūḷhaṃ yathāakusalaṃ, yaṃ tvaṃ dabbaṃ mallaputtaṃ amūlikāya sīlavipattiyā anuddhaṃsesi.
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.13.eng: “You have certainly made a mistake. You’ve been foolish, confused, and unskillful.

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.14.pli: Yato ca kho tvaṃ, āvuso vaḍḍha, accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikarosi, taṃ te mayaṃ paṭiggaṇhāma.
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.14.eng: But since you acknowledge your mistake and make proper amends, I forgive you.

pli-tv-kd15:20.5.15.pli: Vuḍḍhihesā, āvuso vaḍḍha, ariyassa vinaye yo accayaṃ accayato disvā yathādhammaṃ paṭikaroti, āyatiṃ saṃvaraṃ āpajjatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.15.eng: For this is called growth in the training of the noble ones: acknowledging a mistake, making proper amends, and undertaking restraint in the future.”
pli-tv-kd15:20.5.15.comm: For an explanation of the rendering “training” for vinaya, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:20.6.1.eng: The Buddha then addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:20.6.2.pli: “tena hi, bhikkhave, saṅgho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattaṃ ukkujjatu, sambhogaṃ saṅghena karotu.
pli-tv-kd15:20.6.2.eng: “Well then, the Sangha should turn the almsbowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.6.3.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatassa upāsakassa patto ukkujjitabbo—
pli-tv-kd15:20.6.3.eng: When a lay follower has eight qualities, you should turn your bowl upright for him:

pli-tv-kd15:20.6.4.pli: na bhikkhūnaṃ alābhāya parisakkati, na bhikkhūnaṃ anatthāya parisakkati, na bhikkhūnaṃ avāsāya parisakkati, na bhikkhū akkosati paribhāsati, na bhikkhū bhikkhūhi bhedeti, na buddhassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, na dhammassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, na saṅghassa avaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
pli-tv-kd15:20.6.4.eng: he’s not trying to stop monks from getting material support; he’s not trying to harm monks; he’s not trying to get monks to lose their place of residence; he doesn’t abuse or revile monks; he doesn’t cause division between monks; he doesn’t disparage the Buddha; he doesn’t disparage the Teaching; he doesn’t disparage the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.6.5.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imehi aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgatassa upāsakassa pattaṃ ukkujjituṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.1.eng: And the turning of the bowl upright is to be done like this.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.2.pli: Tena, bhikkhave, vaḍḍhena licchavinā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā bhikkhūnaṃ pāde vanditvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā añjaliṃ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo—
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.2.eng: Vaḍḍha the Licchavī should approach the Sangha, arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.3.pli: ‘saṅghena me, bhante, patto nikkujjito, asambhogomhi saṅghena.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.3.eng: ‘Venerables, the Sangha has overturned the bowl against me, prohibiting me from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.4.pli: Sohaṃ, bhante, sammā vattāmi, lomaṃ pātemi, netthāraṃ vattāmi, saṅghaṃ pattukkujjanaṃ yācāmī’ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.4.eng: I’m now conducting myself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released. I ask the Sangha to turn the bowl upright for me.’
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.4.comm: The meaning of the first of these phrases, sammā vattati, is straightforward, but the last two, lomaṁ pāteti and netthāraṁ vattati, are more difficult. Commenting on Bu Ss 13, Sp 1.435 explains: Na lomaṁ pātentīti anulomapaṭipadaṁ appaṭipajjanatāya na pannalomā honti. Na netthāraṁ vattantīti attano nittharaṇamaggaṁ na paṭipajjanti, “Na lomaṁ pātenti: because of their non-practicing in conformity with the path, their bodily hairs are not flat. Na netthāraṁ vattanti: they are not practicing the path for their own getting out (of the offense).” My rendering attempts to capture the meaning in a non-literal way.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.5.eng: And he should ask a second

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.7.eng: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.8.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.9.pli: Saṅghena vaḍḍhassa licchavissa patto nikkujjito, asambhogo saṅghena.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.9.eng: The Sangha has overturned the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.10.pli: So sammā vattati, lomaṃ pāteti, netthāraṃ vattati, saṅghaṃ pattukkujjanaṃ yācati.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.10.eng: He’s now conducting himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and is asking the Sangha to turn the bowl upright for him.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.11.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattaṃ ukkujjeyya, sambhogaṃ saṅghena kareyya.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.11.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should turn the bowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.13.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.14.pli: Saṅghena vaḍḍhassa licchavissa patto nikkujjito, asambhogo saṅghena.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.14.eng: The Sangha has overturned the bowl against Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, prohibiting him from interacting with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.15.pli: So sammā vattati, lomaṃ pāteti, netthāraṃ vattati, saṅghaṃ pattukkujjanaṃ yācati.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.15.eng: He’s now conducting himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and is asking the Sangha to turn the bowl upright for him.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.16.pli: Saṅgho vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattaṃ ukkujjati, sambhogaṃ saṅghena karoti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.16.eng: The Sangha turns the bowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.17.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati vaḍḍhassa licchavissa pattassa ukkujjanā, sambhogaṃ saṅghena karaṇaṃ, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.17.eng: Any monk who approves of turning the bowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.18.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.19.pli: Ukkujjito saṅghena vaḍḍhassa licchavissa patto, sambhogo saṅghena.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.19.eng: The Sangha has turned the bowl upright for Vaḍḍha the Licchavī, allowing him to interact with the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:20.7.20.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:20.7.20.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā vesāliyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena bhaggā tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed at Vesālī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward the country of Bhaggā.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena bhaggā tadavasari.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.3.eng: he stayed at Susumāragira in the Bhesakaḷā Grove, the deer park.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bodhissa rājakumārassa kokanado nāma pāsādo acirakārito hoti, anajjhāvuttho samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.4.eng: At this time Prince Bodhi had recently built the Kokanada stilt house. It had not yet been inhabited by any monastic or brahmin, or anyone else.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.5.pli: Atha kho bodhi rājakumāro sañcikāputtaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.5.eng: The prince said to the young brahmin Sañcikāputta,

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.6.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, samma sañcikāputta, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama, upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vanda;
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.6.eng: “My dear Sañcikāputta, please go to the Buddha, bow down in my name with your head at his feet,

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.7.pli: appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha—

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.8.pli: ‘bodhi, bhante, rājakumāro bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.8.eng: if he’s healthy, strong, and living at ease.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.10.pli: ‘adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā bodhissa rājakumārassa svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.10.eng: ‘Sir, please accept tomorrow’s meal from Prince Bodhi together with the Sangha of monks.’”

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho sañcikāputto māṇavo bodhissa rājakumārassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.11.eng: Saying, “Yes, sir,” Sañcikāputta went to the Buddha and exchanged pleasantries with him. He then sat down

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.12.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sañcikāputto māṇavo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.12.eng: and told the Buddha all he had been asked to say,

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.13.pli: “bodhi kho rājakumāro bhoto gotamassa pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.15.pli: ‘adhivāsetu kira bhavaṃ gotamo bodhissa rājakumārassa svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.1.15.eng: concluding with the invitation for the meal on the following day.

pli-tv-kd15:21.1.16.eng: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.1.pli: Atha kho sañcikāputto māṇavo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bodhi rājakumāro tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bodhiṃ rājakumāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.1.eng: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Sañcikāputta got up from his seat, returned to the prince, and told him what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.2.pli: “avocumha kho mayaṃ bhoto vacanena taṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ—

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.3.pli: ‘bodhi kho rājakumāro bhoto gotamassa pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.5.pli: adhivāsetu kira bhavaṃ gotamo bodhissa rājakumārassa svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’ti.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.7.pli: Atha kho bodhi rājakumāro tassā rattiyā accayena paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā, kokanadañca pāsādaṃ odātehi dussehi santharāpetvā yāva pacchimasopānakaḷevarā, sañcikāputtaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.7.eng: The next morning Prince Bodhi had various kinds of fine foods prepared, and had the entire Kokanada stilt house covered with white cloth, all the way to the bottom step of the staircase. He then said to Sañcikāputta,

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.8.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, samma sañcikāputta, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocehi—

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.9.eng: and tell him the meal is ready.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho sañcikāputto māṇavo bodhissa rājakumārassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocesi—

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.12.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena bodhissa rājakumārassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.12.eng: Soon afterwards, the Buddha robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and went the prince’s house.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bodhi rājakumāro bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhito hoti, bhagavantaṃ āgamayamāno.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.13.eng: The prince was standing outside the gatehouse, waiting for the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.14.pli: Addasā kho bodhi rājakumāro bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.14.eng: When he saw the Buddha coming,

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.15.pli: Disvāna tato paccuggantvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā purekkhatvā yena kokanado pāsādo tenupasaṅkami.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.15.eng: he went out to meet him, bowed down to him, and then returned to the Kokanada stilt house with the Buddha in front.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.16.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pacchimasopānakaḷevaraṃ nissāya aṭṭhāsi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.16.eng: But the Buddha stopped at the bottom stair of that staircase.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.17.pli: Atha kho bodhi rājakumāro bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.18.pli: “akkamatu, bhante, bhagavā dussāni, akkamatu sugato dussāni, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.18.eng: “Sir, please step on the cloth. It will be for my long-term benefit and happiness.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.20.eng: A second time the prince repeated his request, but the Buddha still remained silent.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.21.pli: tatiyampi kho bodhi rājakumāro bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.21.eng: When the prince made his request for the third time,

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.22.pli: “akkamatu, bhante, bhagavā dussāni, akkamatu sugato dussāni, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.23.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ apalokesi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.23.eng: the Buddha looked at Venerable Ānanda.

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.24.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bodhiṃ rājakumāraṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.24.eng: And Ānanda said to the prince,

pli-tv-kd15:21.2.26.pli: Na bhagavā celapaṭikaṃ akkamissati pacchimaṃ janataṃ tathāgato anukampatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.2.26.eng: The Buddha doesn’t step on cloth coverings. He has compassion for later generations.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.1.pli: Atha kho bodhi rājakumāro dussāni saṃharāpetvā uparikokanade pāsāde āsanaṃ paññapesi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.3.1.eng: The prince then had the cloth folded up and had a seat prepared up in the stilt house.

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā kokanadaṃ pāsādaṃ abhiruhitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
pli-tv-kd15:21.3.2.eng: The Buddha ascended the house and sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.3.pli: Atha kho bodhi rājakumāro buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā, bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ, ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.3.3.eng: The prince personally served the various kinds of fine foods to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal and had washed his hands and bowl, the prince sat down to one side.

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho bodhiṃ rājakumāraṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd15:21.3.4.eng: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd15:21.3.5.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.6.eng: “You shouldn’t step on a cloth covering.

pli-tv-kd15:21.3.7.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarā itthī apagatagabbhā bhikkhū nimantetvā dussaṃ paññapetvā etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.1.eng: On one occasion a woman who was unable to conceive invited the monks, prepared a cloth, and said,

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.3.eng: But being afraid of wrongdoing, they refused.

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.4.eng: “Please step on the cloth as a blessing.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.6.pli: Atha kho sā itthī ujjhāyati khiyyati vipāceti—
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.6.eng: That woman complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.7.pli: “kathañhi nāma ayyā maṅgalatthāya yāciyamānā celapaṭikaṃ na akkamissantī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.7.eng: “How can the venerables not step on a cloth as a blessing when asked?”

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.8.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tassā itthiyā ujjhāyantiyā khiyyantiyā vipācentiyā.
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.8.eng: The monks heard the complaints of that woman,

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.9.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.9.eng: and they told the Buddha what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.11.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, gihīnaṃ maṅgalatthāya yāciyamānena celapaṭikaṃ akkamitun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.11.eng: I allow you, when asked, to step on a cloth covering as a blessing for householders.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.12.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū dhotapādakaṃ akkamituṃ kukkuccāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.12.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not step on a towel after washing their feet.

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.14.eng: “I allow you to step on a towel after washing your feet.”
pli-tv-kd15:21.4.14.comm: Sp 4.268: Dhotapādakaṁ nāma pādadhovanaṭṭhāne dhotehi pādehi akkamanatthāya paccattharaṇaṁ atthataṁ hoti, taṁ akkamituṁ vaṭṭati, “Dhotapādaka: a mat that has been spread out for the purpose of stepping on with the washed feet at the place of washing the feet. To step on that is allowable.”

pli-tv-kd15:21.4.15.eng: The second section for recitation is finished.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.0.eng: More regulations on proper conduct and allowable requisites.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bhaggesu yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in the country of Bhaggā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi tadavasari.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.3.eng: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.4.pli: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā ghaṭakañca katakañca sammajjaniñca ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.4.eng: Soon Visākhā Migāramātā went to the Buddha, taking a waterpot, a ceramic foot scrubber, and a broom. She bowed to the Buddha, sat down,
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.4.comm: That the foot scrubber, the kataka, is ceramic is clear from Kd 15:37.1.8 below.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho visākhā migāramātā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.6.pli: “paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā ghaṭakañca katakañca sammajjaniñca, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.6.eng: “Sir, for my long-term benefit and happiness, please accept this waterpot, foot scrubber, and broom.”

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.7.eng: The Buddha accepted the waterpot and the broom,

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.8.eng: but not the ceramic foot scrubber.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā visākhaṃ migāramātaraṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.9.eng: He then instructed, inspired, and gladdened her with a teaching,

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.10.pli: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.10.eng: after which she got up from her seat, bowed down, circumambulated him with her right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.11.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd15:22.1.11.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.13.eng: But you shouldn’t use a ceramic foot scrubber.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.14.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.15.eng: I allow three kinds of foot scrubbers:

pli-tv-kd15:22.1.16.comm: “Stones” renders sakkhara. Sp 4.269: Sakkharāti pāsāṇo vuccati, “A rock is called sakkhara.” “Pumice” renders samuddapheṇaka, literally, “ocean foam”. Sp 4.269: Pāsāṇapheṇakopi vaṭṭati, “Also rock-foam is allowable”.

pli-tv-kd15:22.2.1.pli: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā vidhūpanañca tālavaṇṭañca ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
pli-tv-kd15:22.2.1.eng: Visākhā again went to the Buddha, now taking a standard fan and a palm-leaf fan. She bowed, sat down,

pli-tv-kd15:22.2.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho visākhā migāramātā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-kd15:22.2.3.pli: “paṭiggaṇhātu me, bhante, bhagavā vidhūpanañca tālavaṇṭañca, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:22.2.3.eng: “Sir, for my long-term benefit and happiness, please accept this standard fan and this palm-leaf fan.”

pli-tv-kd15:22.2.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā visākhaṃ migāramātaraṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:22.2.5.eng: He then instructed, inspired, and gladdened her with a teaching, after which she got up from her seat, bowed, circumambulated him with her right side toward him,

pli-tv-kd15:22.2.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe dhammiṃ kathaṃ katvā bhikkhū āmantesi—
pli-tv-kd15:22.2.7.eng: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:22.2.8.eng: “I allow standard fans and a palm-leaf fans.”
pli-tv-kd15:22.2.8.comm: “A fan” renders vidhūpana. Sp 4.269: Vidhūpananti vījanī vuccati, “A fan is called a vidhūpana.” To distinguish it from the “palm-leaf fan”, I render it as “standard fan”.

pli-tv-kd15:23.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa makasabījanī uppannā hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.1.1.eng: On one occasion the Sangha was offered a mosquito whisk.

pli-tv-kd15:23.1.4.eng: The Sangha was offered a yak-tail whisk.

pli-tv-kd15:23.1.7.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:23.1.8.eng: I allow three kinds of fans:

pli-tv-kd15:23.1.9.eng: those made of bark, vetiver grass, and peacocks’ tail feathers.”

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saṅghassa chattaṃ uppannaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.1.eng: On one occasion the Sangha was offered a sunshade.

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū chattappaggahitā āhiṇḍanti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.4.eng: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six walked about holding sunshades.

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro upāsako sambahulehi ājīvakasāvakehi saddhiṃ uyyānaṃ agamāsi.
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.5.eng: Then, as a certain Buddhist lay follower and a number of Ājīvaka disciples were going to the park,

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.6.pli: Addasāsuṃ kho te ājīvakasāvakā chabbaggiye bhikkhū dūratova chattappaggahite āgacchante.
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.6.eng: the Ājīvakas saw those monks in the distance with their sunshades.

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.7.eng: They said to that lay follower,

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.8.pli: “ete kho ayyā tumhākaṃ bhadantā chattappaggahitā āgacchanti, seyyathāpi gaṇakamahāmattā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.8.eng: “These venerables of yours are coming. They’re holding sunshades, just like accountants and government officials.”

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.10.eng: And they made a bet on whether they were monks or not.

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.11.pli: Atha kho so upāsako upagate sañjānitvā ujjhāyati khiyyati vipāceti—
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.11.eng: When the monks came close, that lay follower recognized them. And he complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.12.eng: “How can the venerables walk about holding sunshades?”

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.13.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tassa upāsakassa ujjhāyantassa khiyyantassa vipācentassa.
pli-tv-kd15:23.2.13.eng: The monks heard the complaints of that lay follower

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.14.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.15.eng: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are doing this?”

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.18.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:23.2.20.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:23.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu gilāno hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.3.1.eng: Soon afterwards a certain sick monk

pli-tv-kd15:23.3.2.pli: Tassa bhikkhuno vinā chattaṃ na phāsu hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.3.2.eng: was not comfortable without a sunshade.

pli-tv-kd15:23.3.4.eng: “I allow sick monks to use sunshades.”

pli-tv-kd15:23.4.2.pli: gilānasseva bhagavatā chattaṃ anuññātaṃ no agilānassāti—
pli-tv-kd15:23.4.2.eng: that the Buddha had allowed sunshades for the sick, but not for the healthy,

pli-tv-kd15:23.4.3.eng: and being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not use sunshades in the monastery or in the vicinity of the monastery.

pli-tv-kd15:23.4.5.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, agilānenapi ārāme ārāmūpacāre chattaṃ dhāretun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:23.4.5.eng: “I allow you to use a sunshade in a monastery and in the vicinity of a monastery, even if you’re healthy.”

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu sikkāya pattaṃ uṭṭitvā daṇḍe ālaggetvā vikāle aññatarena gāmadvārena atikkamati.
pli-tv-kd15:24.1.1.eng: On one occasion a monk put his almsbowl in a carrying net, hung it from a staff, and passed through the gateway to a certain village at an unusual hour.
pli-tv-kd15:24.1.1.comm: “Carrying net” renders sikkā. Vin-vn-ṭ 91: Sikkāyāti olambikādhāre, “Sikkā means a holder for hanging.” CPD, sv. uḍḍeti, says, “To put in a sling or carrying net”, evidently referring to the sikkā.

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.3.pli: “esayyo coro gacchati, asissa vijjotalatī”ti anupatitvā gahetvā sañjānitvā muñciṃsu.
pli-tv-kd15:24.1.3.eng: “This must be a gangster coming with his gleaming sword.” They pounced and seized him, but when they recognized him, they let him go.

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.4.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd15:24.1.4.eng: He returned to the monastery and told the monks what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.5.eng: They said, “So you used a carrying net and a staff?”

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.7.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd15:24.1.7.eng: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.8.eng: “How can a monk use a carrying net and a staff?”

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.9.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.12.eng: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.13.eng: “You shouldn’t use a carrying net and a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.1.14.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu gilāno hoti, na sakkoti vinā daṇḍena āhiṇḍituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.1.eng: On one occasion there was a sick monk who was unable to walk about without a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.3.eng: “I allow you to give a sick monk permission to use a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.4.eng: And it should be given like this.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.5.pli: Tena gilānena bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā vuḍḍhānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pāde vanditvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā añjaliṃ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo—
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.5.eng: The sick monk should approach the Sangha, arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.7.eng: I’m unable to walk about without a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.8.eng: I ask the Sangha for permission to use a staff.’

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.9.eng: And he should ask a second

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.11.eng: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.12.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.13.pli: Ayaṃ itthannāmo bhikkhu gilāno, na sakkoti vinā daṇḍena āhiṇḍituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.13.eng: Monk so-and-so is sick. He’s unable to walk about without a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.14.eng: He’s asking the Sangha for permission to use a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.15.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmassa bhikkhuno daṇḍasammutiṃ dadeyya.
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.15.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should give monk so-and-so permission to use a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.17.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.18.pli: Ayaṃ itthannāmo bhikkhu gilāno, na sakkoti vinā daṇḍena āhiṇḍituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.18.eng: Monk so-and-so is sick. He’s unable to walk about without a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.19.eng: He’s asking the Sangha for permission to use a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.20.eng: The Sangha gives monk so-and-so permission to use a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.21.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno daṇḍasammutiyā dānaṃ, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.21.eng: Any monk who approves of this should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.22.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.23.eng: The Sangha has given monk so-and-so permission to use a staff.

pli-tv-kd15:24.2.24.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:24.2.24.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu gilāno hoti, na sakkoti vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.1.eng: On one occasion there was a sick monk who was unable to carry his almsbowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.3.eng: “I allow you to give a sick monk permission to use a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.4.eng: And it should be given like this.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.5.pli: Tena gilānena bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā vuḍḍhānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pāde vanditvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā añjaliṃ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo—
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.5.eng: The sick monk should approach the Sangha, arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.7.pli: na sakkomi vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.7.eng: I’m unable to carry my bowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.8.eng: I ask the Sangha for permission to use a carrying net.’

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.9.eng: And he should ask a second

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.11.eng: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.12.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.13.pli: Ayaṃ itthannāmo bhikkhu gilāno, na sakkoti vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.13.eng: Monk so-and-so is sick. He’s unable to carry his bowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.14.eng: He’s asking the Sangha for permission to use a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.15.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmassa bhikkhuno sikkāsammutiṃ dadeyya.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.15.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should give monk so-and-so permission to use a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.17.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.18.pli: Ayaṃ itthannāmo bhikkhu gilāno, na sakkoti vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.18.eng: Monk so-and-so is sick. He’s unable to carry his bowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.19.eng: He’s asking the Sangha for permission to use a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.20.eng: The Sangha gives monk so-and-so permission to use a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.21.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno sikkāsammutiyā dānaṃ, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.21.eng: Any monk who approves of this should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.22.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.23.eng: The Sangha has given monk so-and-so permission to use a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.24.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.24.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.25.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu gilāno hoti, na sakkoti vinā daṇḍena āhiṇḍituṃ, na sakkoti vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.25.eng: On one occasion there was a sick monk who was unable to walk about without a staff or to carry his almsbowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.27.eng: “I allow you to give a sick monk permission to use a staff and a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.28.eng: And it should be given like this.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.29.pli: Tena gilānena bhikkhunā saṅghaṃ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā vuḍḍhānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pāde vanditvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā añjaliṃ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo—
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.29.eng: The sick monk should approach the Sangha, arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and say:

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.31.eng: I’m unable to walk about without a staff

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.32.pli: na sakkomi vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.32.eng: or to carry my bowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.33.eng: I ask the Sangha to give me permission to use a staff and a carrying net.’

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.34.eng: And he should ask a second

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.36.eng: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.37.eng: ‘Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.38.pli: Ayaṃ itthannāmo bhikkhu gilāno, na sakkoti vinā daṇḍena āhiṇḍituṃ, na sakkoti vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.38.eng: Monk so-and-so is sick. He’s unable to walk about without a staff or to carry his bowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.39.eng: He’s asking the Sangha for permission to use a staff and a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.40.pli: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho itthannāmassa bhikkhuno daṇḍasikkāsammutiṃ dadeyya.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.40.eng: If the Sangha is ready, it should give monk so-and-so permission to use a staff and a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.42.eng: Please, venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.43.pli: Ayaṃ itthannāmo bhikkhu gilāno na sakkoti vinā daṇḍena āhiṇḍituṃ, na sakkoti vinā sikkāya pattaṃ pariharituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.43.eng: Monk so-and-so is sick. He’s unable to walk about without a staff or to carry his bowl without a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.44.eng: He’s asking the Sangha for permission to use a staff and a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.45.eng: The Sangha gives monk so-and-so permission to use a staff and a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.46.pli: Yassāyasmato khamati itthannāmassa bhikkhuno daṇḍasikkāsammutiyā dānaṃ, so tuṇhassa;
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.46.eng: Any monk who approves of this should remain silent.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.47.eng: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.48.eng: The Sangha has given monk so-and-so permission to use a staff and a carrying net.

pli-tv-kd15:24.3.49.pli: Khamati saṅghassa, tasmā tuṇhī, evametaṃ dhārayāmī’”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:24.3.49.eng: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu romanthako hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:25.1.1.eng: At that time there was a monk who was a regurgitator.

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.3.eng: The monks complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.4.eng: “This monk is eating at the wrong time.”

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.6.eng: “This monk has only recently passed away as a cow.

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.7.eng: I allow a regurgitator to regurgitate.

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.8.pli: Na ca, bhikkhave, bahimukhadvāraṃ nīharitvā ajjhoharitabbaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:25.1.8.eng: But you shouldn’t take it out of the mouth and then swallow it.

pli-tv-kd15:25.1.9.eng: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa pūgassa saṅghabhattaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:26.1.1.eng: Soon afterwards a certain association was offering a meal to the Sangha.

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.2.eng: Lots of rice fell on the floor in the dining hall.

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.4.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā odane diyyamāne na sakkaccaṃ paṭiggahessanti, ekamekaṃ sitthaṃ kammasatena niṭṭhāyatī”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:26.1.4.eng: “When they’re given rice, how can the Sakyan monastics not receive it with care? Each lump of rice is the result of hard work.”

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.5.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:26.1.5.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people.

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.6.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.7.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, yaṃ diyyamānaṃ patati, taṃ sāmaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjituṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:26.1.7.eng: “I allow you to pick up and eat what falls down while being given.

pli-tv-kd15:26.1.8.eng: It has been relinquished by the donors.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu dīghehi nakhehi piṇḍāya carati.
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.1.eng: On one occasion a certain monk with long nails was walking for alms.

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.2.pli: Aññatarā itthī passitvā taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.2.eng: A woman who saw him said to him,

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.5.pli: “Sace kho tvaṃ, bhante, nappaṭisevissasi, idānāhaṃ attano nakhehi gattāni vilikhitvā kuppaṃ karissāmi—
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.5.eng: “If you don’t, I’ll scratch my limbs with my nails and make a scene,

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.7.comm: Pajānāhi tvaṁ, bhaginīti, literally, “You understand, sister.” Commenting on a different context, DN-a 2.436 says: Tvaṁ pajānāhīti tvaṁ jāna. Sace gaṇhitukāmosi, gaṇhāhīti vuttaṁ hoti, “You understand: you know. What is said is: if you wish to take it, then take it.” In other words, do as you please.

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.8.pli: Atha kho sā itthī attano nakhehi gattāni vilikhitvā kuppaṃ akāsi—
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.8.eng: Yet that woman did as she had threatened.

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.10.eng: People rushed up and took hold of that monk.

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.11.pli: Addasāsuṃ kho te manussā tassā itthiyā nakhe chavimpi lohitampi.
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.11.eng: But when they saw the skin and blood on that woman’s nails,

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.15.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.15.eng: He then returned to the monastery and told the monks what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.16.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, āvuso, dīghe nakhe dhāresī”ti?

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.18.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd15:27.1.18.eng: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.19.eng: “How can a monk grow his nails long?”

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.20.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ.

pli-tv-kd15:27.1.22.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū nakhenapi nakhaṃ chindanti, mukhenapi nakhaṃ chindanti, kuṭṭepi ghaṃsanti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.2.1.eng: Soon afterwards the monks were cutting their nails with their nails and teeth, or by grinding them on walls.

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.5.eng: They cut their nails so short that they bled.

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.7.eng: “You should cut your nails so that they’re even with the tip of the flesh.”
pli-tv-kd15:27.2.7.comm: “Even with the tip of the flesh” renders maṁsappamāṇena. Vin-ālaṅ-ṭ 34.40: Maṁsappamāṇenāti aṅgulaggamaṁsappamāṇena, “Maṁsappamāṇena: measured by the flesh at the tip of the finger.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.8.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū vīsatimaṭṭhaṃ kārāpenti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.2.8.eng: At this time the monks from the group of six polished their finger and toe nails.
pli-tv-kd15:27.2.8.comm: “Polished their finger and toe nails” renders vīsatimaṭṭhaṁ, literally, “Polished the twenty”. Sp 4.274: Vīsatimaṭṭhanti vīsatipi nakhe likhitamaṭṭhe kārāpenti, “Vīsatimaṭṭhaṁ: they polished their twenty nails.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.10.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.12.eng: “You shouldn’t polish your finger and toe nails.

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.13.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:27.2.14.eng: But I allow you to remove dirt.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhūnaṃ kesā dīghā honti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.3.1.eng: At that time there were monks who had long hair.

pli-tv-kd15:27.3.3.pli: “Ussahanti pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhū aññamaññaṃ kese oropetun”ti?
pli-tv-kd15:27.3.3.eng: “Are you able to shave each other’s heads?”

pli-tv-kd15:27.3.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etasmiṃ nidāne etasmiṃ pakaraṇe bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:27.3.5.eng: The Buddha then gave a teaching

pli-tv-kd15:27.3.7.pli: “anujānāmi, bhikkhave, khuraṃ khurasilaṃ khurasipāṭikaṃ namatakaṃ sabbaṃ khurabhaṇḍan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.3.7.eng: “I allow a razor, a whetstone, a razor case, felt, and all barber equipment.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū massuṃ kappāpenti …pe…
pli-tv-kd15:27.4.1.eng: At this time the monks from the group of six trimmed their beards,

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.3.comm: “Goatees” renders golomikaṁ kārāpenti. Sp 4.275: Golomikanti hanukamhi dīghaṁ katvā ṭhapitaṁ eḷakamassu vuccati, “Making it long at the jaw, a beard like that of a goat is called golomika.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.4.comm: “Sideburns” renders caturassakaṁ kārāpenti. Sp 4.275: Caturassakanti catukoṇaṁ, “Caturassaka: the four-cornered one.” This is further explained by Vmv 4.275: Catukoṇanti yathā upari nalāṭantesu dve, heṭṭhā hanukapasse dveti cattāro koṇā paññāyanti, evaṁ caturassaṁ katvā kappāpanaṁ, “Catukoṇa: when four corners are seen—two above at the end of the forehead and two below on the side of the jaw—trimming it, having made it four-cornered like this.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.5.comm: Sp 4.275: Parimukhanti ure lomasaṁharaṇaṁ, “Parimukha: removing the hair from the chest.” It is a stretch, however, to take parimukha as referring to the chest, rather than the face or the mouth. Assuming that beard fashions are fairly timeless, it seems possible that this may refer to a beard around the mouth, that is, a circle beard.

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.6.comm: My rendering is based on the reading aḍḍhuraka. Sp 4.275: Aḍḍhadukanti udare lomarājiṭṭhapanaṁ, “Aḍḍhaduka: arrangement of lines of hair on the stomach.” The problem with this is that it is difficult to see how this meaning bears any relationship with aḍḍhaduka. In fact, aḍḍhaduka is a curious word. On the face of it, it should mean “half a dyad”, but this hardly makes much sense in the context. A major problem with aḍḍhaduka is that the reading is highly uncertain. The Buddha Jayantī Tipiṭaka of Sri Lanka gives the alternative aḍḍhuraka, SRT aḍḍharuka, and the PTS edition aḍḍharūka. The first of these is particularly interesting: it almost certainly means “half-chest-ed”. It could well be that this is the basis for the commentarial gloss. The actual commentarial reading (the lemma) may be due to a later “correction”, perhaps based on a change in the Canonical text. If we start with aḍḍhuraka as the original form, it is relatively easy to explain the other two forms, which weighs in favor of this reading. Aḍḍharuka can be explained as an a/u metathesis in aḍḍhuraka, which is all too common in oral tradition, especially with obscure words. Once the meaning was lost, aḍḍhaduka may have formed as a kind of further corruption, either by accident or through intentional “correction”. We would then see the following pattern of corruption: aḍḍhuraka > aḍḍharuka > aḍḍhaduka.

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.8.eng: and removed the hair from their private parts.

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.10.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.19.eng: or remove the hair from your private parts.

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.20.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.21.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno sambādhe vaṇo hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.4.21.eng: A certain monk had a sore on his private parts,

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.22.eng: and the medicine did not stick.

pli-tv-kd15:27.4.24.eng: “I allow you to remove hair from the private parts if you have a disease.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū kattarikāya kese chedāpenti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.5.1.eng: At that time the monks from the group of six cut their hair with scissors.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.3.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.5.eng: “You shouldn’t cut your hair with scissors.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno sīse vaṇo hoti, na sakkoti khurena kese oropetuṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:27.5.7.eng: A monk who had a sore on his head was unable to shave with a razor.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.9.eng: “I allow you to cut your hair with scissors if you have a disease.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.10.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū dīghāni nāsikālomāni dhārenti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.5.10.eng: At this time there were monks who grew their nasal hair long.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.14.eng: “You shouldn’t grow your nasal hair long.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.15.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.16.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū sakkharikāyapi madhusitthakenapi nāsikālomaṃ gāhāpenti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.5.16.eng: The monks had their nasal hair removed with small stones and beeswax.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.20.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū palitaṃ gāhāpenti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.5.20.eng: The monks from the group of six had their gray hairs removed.

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.22.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:27.5.25.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:27.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhikkhuno kaṇṇagūthakehi kaṇṇā thakitā honti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.6.1.eng: On one occasion a monk’s ear was blocked by earwax.

pli-tv-kd15:27.6.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacā kaṇṇamalaharaṇiyo dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:27.6.4.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six used luxurious earpicks made with gold and silver.

pli-tv-kd15:27.6.6.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:27.6.9.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:27.6.10.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, aṭṭhimayaṃ dantamayaṃ visāṇamayaṃ naḷamayaṃ veḷumayaṃ kaṭṭhamayaṃ jatumayaṃ phalamayaṃ lohamayaṃ saṅkhanābhimayan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:27.6.10.eng: I allow earpicks made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, or shell.”
pli-tv-kd15:27.6.10.comm: “Made of fruit” renders phalamaya. Khuddasikkhā-purāṇaṭīkā 185: Āmalakakakkādīhi katā phalamayā, “Made of fruit means made from ground emblic myrobalan, etc.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.1.0.eng: More regulations on proper conduct and allowable requisites

pli-tv-kd15:28.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū bahuṃ lohabhaṇḍaṃ kaṃsabhaṇḍaṃ sannicayaṃ karonti.
pli-tv-kd15:28.1.1.eng: At one time the monks from the group of six had amassed a large number of metal and bronze goods.

pli-tv-kd15:28.1.2.pli: Manussā vihāracārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā passitvā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-kd15:28.1.2.eng: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,

pli-tv-kd15:28.1.3.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā bahuṃ lohabhaṇḍaṃ kaṃsabhaṇḍaṃ sannicayaṃ karissanti, seyyathāpi kaṃsapattharikā”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:28.1.3.eng: “How can the Sakyan monastics amass a large number of metal and bronze goods? They’re just like merchants.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.1.5.pli: “Na, bhikkhave, bahuṃ lohabhaṇḍaṃ kaṃsabhaṇḍaṃ sannicayo kātabbo.
pli-tv-kd15:28.1.5.eng: “You shouldn’t amass a large number of metal and bronze goods.

pli-tv-kd15:28.1.6.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū añjanimpi añjanisalākampi kaṇṇamalaharaṇimpi bandhanamattampi kukkuccāyanti.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.1.eng: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept ointment boxes, ointment sticks, earpicks, or even metal used for binding.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.1.comm: “Even metal used for binding” renders bandhanamatta. Vmv 4.277: Bandhanamattanti vāsidaṇḍādīnaṁ koṭīsu apātanatthaṁ, lohehi bandhanaṁ, “Bandhanamatta: bindings of metal used for the purpose of the non-falling off at the top end of the handle of an adz, etc.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.3.eng: “I allow ointment boxes, ointment sticks, earpicks, and metal used for binding.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū saṅghāṭipallatthikāya nisīdanti.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.4.eng: On one occasion the monks from the group of six were sitting with their upper robes as a back-and-knee strap.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.4.comm: This refers to using the upper robe as a support in the pallatthikā sitting posture. See Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita, “Analysis of the Bhikkhu Pātimokkha”, p. 259 (re. Bu Sk 26:1.3.1).

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.5.eng: The panels of the robes were torn apart.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.5.comm: Sp 3.359: Pattā lujjantīti mahantesu pattamukhesu dinnāni suttāni gaḷanti, tato pattā lujjanti, “Pattā lujjanti: concerning large openings in the panels, the sewing thread had vanished; therefore the panels were torn apart.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.7.eng: “You shouldn’t sit with your upper robe as a back-and-knee strap.

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.9.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu gilāno hoti.

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.10.pli: Tassa vinā āyogena na phāsu hoti.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.10.eng: who was not comfortable without a back-and-knee strap.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.10.comm: The āyoga is used as a support for the pallattikā sitting posture.

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.14.eng: “How are the back-and-knee straps to be made?”

pli-tv-kd15:28.2.16.pli: “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, tantakaṃ vemaṃ kavaṭaṃ salākaṃ sabbaṃ tantabhaṇḍakan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.16.eng: “I allow a warp, a reed, a weft, a shuttle, and all weaving equipment.”
pli-tv-kd15:28.2.16.comm: “Warp” renders tantaka. Vmv 4.277: Tantakanti āyogavāyanatthaṁ tadākārena pasāritatantaṁ, “The stretched thread by means of which the purpose of weaving the back-and-knee strap (is achieved).” It is curious, however, that the loom is missing from this list of weaving equipment. It is possible that tantaka is merely another term for tanta “a loom”. “Reed” renders vema. Commenting on Bu Np 26, Kkh-pṭ says: Vemanti vāyanūpakaraṇo eko daṇḍo, suttaṁ pavesetvā yena ākoṭento ghanabhāvaṁ sampādenti, “Vema: a weaving instrument consisting of a single rod; having entered the thread, that by which they make it firm by knocking.” Vmv 4.277 clarifies that this concerns the cross-going thread, the weft: Vāyantā tiriyaṁ suttaṁ pavesetvā …, “Those weaving, having entered the weft …” According to SED, however, the vema is the loom. “Weft” renders kavaṭa. I am unable to trace any exegetical information on this word; quite possibly the reading is corrupted. It may be that we should prefer the PTS reading of vaṭa, which can mean “string” or “tie”, according to SED. Since the warp seems to be covered by tantaka, it does not seem unreasonable to suggest vaṭa refers to the “weft”, that is, the cross-thread. “Shuttle” renders salāka. The basic meaning of this word is “small stick”. In the Vinaya Piṭaka the word salāka is used especially to designate the “voting tickets” that were sometimes used when making decisions in the monastic Sangha. The “shuttle” is a basic weaving equipment and its size would seem to fit well with the size of a salāka. However, since there is no exegetical information on this word used in this context, this is no more than a hypothesis.

pli-tv-kd15:29.1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu akāyabandhano gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
pli-tv-kd15:29.1.1.eng: On one occasion a monk went to the village for alms without a belt.

pli-tv-kd15:29.1.2.eng: His sarong fell off on the street.

pli-tv-kd15:29.1.5.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd15:29.1.5.eng: When he had returned to the monastery, he told the monks what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:29.1.6.eng: They in turn told the Buddha, who said:

pli-tv-kd15:29.1.7.eng: “You shouldn’t enter an inhabited area without a belt.
pli-tv-kd15:29.1.7.comm: For the rendering “inhabited area” for gāma, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-kd15:29.1.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacāni kāyabandhanāni dhārenti—
pli-tv-kd15:29.2.1.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six wore luxurious belts:

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.2.eng: belts with multiple strings, belts like the head of a water snake, belts of twisted strings of various colors, belts like ornamental ropes.
pli-tv-kd15:29.2.2.comm: Sp 4.278: Kalābukaṁ nāma bahurajjukaṁ, “Kalābuka: one having many strings.” Sp 4.278: Deḍḍubhakaṁ nāma udakasappasīsasadisaṁ, “Deḍḍubhaka: one that is like the head of a water snake.” Sp-ṭ 1.85: Murajañhi nāma nānāvaṇṇehi suttehi murajavaṭṭisaṇṭhānaṁ veṭhetvā kataṁ, “Muraja: one that is made by the twisting of strings of various colors in the manner of the skin of a muraja drum.” Sp 4.275: Maddavīṇaṁ nāma pāmaṅgasaṇṭhānaṁ, “Maddavīṇa: it looks like an ornamental hanging string.”

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.4.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.8.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.9.eng: I allow two kinds of belts:

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.10.eng: belts made from strips of cloth and from pigs’ intestines.”

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.11.eng: The edges of the belts wore away.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.12.eng: “I allow belts of twisted strings of various colors and belts like ornamental ropes.”
pli-tv-kd15:29.2.12.comm: Sp 4.278: Idaṁ dasāsuyeva anuññātaṁ, “This is only allowed in regard to the edges.” According to the commentary, in other words, the Buddha is not overturning the prohibition found in the previous rule.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.13.eng: The ends of the belts wore away.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.14.eng: “I allow making a loop and a knot.”
pli-tv-kd15:29.2.14.comm: Sp 4.278: Sobhaṇaṁ nāma veṭhetvā mukhavaṭṭisibbanaṁ, “Sobhaṇa: having twisted, sewing along the edge of the opening.” Sp 4.278: Guṇakaṁ nāma mudiṅgasaṇṭhānena sibbanaṁ, “Guṇaka: sewing with the appearance of a mudiṅga drum”, which according to Sp-ṭ 4.278 means: Mudiṅgasaṇṭhānenāti varakasīsākārena, “Mudiṅgasaṇṭhānena: with the characteristic of the head of the varaka bean.” It is not clear what is meant. Perhaps the point is that one end of the belt should form a loop and the other a knot, with the knot fitting into the loop.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.15.eng: The loop at the end wore away.
pli-tv-kd15:29.2.15.comm: Sp 4.275: Pavanantoti pāsanto vuccati, “The loop-end is called pavananta.”

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.17.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvace vidhe dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:29.2.17.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six wore luxurious buckles made with gold and silver.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.19.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.22.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:29.2.23.eng: I allow buckles made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal,

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando lahukā saṅghāṭiyo pārupitvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.1.eng: On one occasion Venerable Ānanda robed up in light upper robes and went to the village for alms.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.2.eng: A whirlwind lifted up his robes.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando ārāmaṃ gantvā bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.3.eng: When he had returned to the monastery, he told the monks what had happened.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.4.eng: They in turn told the Buddha.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū uccāvacā gaṇṭhikāyo dhārenti sovaṇṇamayaṃ rūpiyamayaṃ.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.6.eng: Soon the monks from the group of six wore luxurious toggles made with gold and silver.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.8.eng: “They’re just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.11.eng: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.12.pli: Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, aṭṭhimayaṃ dantamayaṃ visāṇamayaṃ naḷamayaṃ veḷumayaṃ kaṭṭhamayaṃ jatumayaṃ phalamayaṃ lohamayaṃ saṅkhanābhimayaṃ suttamayan”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.12.eng: I allow toggles made of bone, ivory, horn, reed, bamboo, wood, resin, fruit, metal, shell, and string.”

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.13.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhikkhū gaṇṭhikampi pāsakampi cīvare appenti.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.13.eng: When the monks fastened toggles and loops to their robes,

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.14.eng: they caused the robes to wear.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.16.eng: “I allow toggle shields and loop shields.”

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.17.eng: They fastened the toggle shields and the loop shields on the edge of the robe.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.18.eng: The corners of the robe separated.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.18.comm: Reading koṇa with SRT, as against koṭṭa of MS.

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.20.eng: “I allow you to fasten the toggle shields at the edge

pli-tv-kd15:29.3.21.pli: pāsakaphalakaṃ sattaṅgulaṃ vā aṭṭhaṅgulaṃ vā ogāhetvā appetun”ti.
pli-tv-kd15:29.3.21.eng: and the loop shields twelve or thirteen centimeters in from the edge.”
